description: I have been to all their locations. Best Chinese food in the city, hands down...their chilli sauce is an addiction.
author: Sunil R.

description: I ordered two entrees of smoked ham and garlic chicken for dinner.  They both look the same and taste the same except different meat.  Very disappointed.
author: Su-Tsen W.

description: Pretty good Chinese place in San Francisco. I miss the original restaurant in SF which was way larger and more homey than this one. However, the food and famous potstickers were still amazing. I grew up eating at Henry's Hunan so I may be biased. Other than the location and environment change, the food is still very tasty!
author: Joanmarie S.

description: Typical Chinese-American dishes at affordable prices and not much foot traffic, making it easier to actually hear the discussions without having to shout. Not the best Chinese food, but decent.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
I went to Hunan for my surprise birthday lunch. All my team mates are vegetarians and they really dig this place because of there fried rice. We went around 12:30, the place is huge and was semi packed. It a two story restaurant, we were 6 people and the gave us a table upstairs. 
The server started by serving us green tea and handing us the menus. After scanning through the menu I picked Kung pao shrimp and my team mates picked fried rice without egg.
I was hoping to get rice with the shrimp order but there was nothing on the side. The shrimps were nicely cooked, spicy, tossed with onions and bell peppers. 
Fried rice were just like any other fried rice with chopped vegetables, I felt they could have made it more tangy or spicy. 
Overall, I don't see myself going to Hunan again. There are many other Chinese restaurants in the city I would wanna try !!!
author: Simran K.

description: You don't go to Henry's for the ambience; you go for the food. And they do the food very well. The dishes are basic - nothing fancy here - but everything is flavored just right, the portions are generous, and staff are friendly and courteous. Go soon after opening to avoid what is sometimes a huge lunch take-out rush.
author: Steve K.

description:
Went today after not eating there in years to order take out.

Had the Harvest Pork Thursday special for $8.95.  Overall, I'd give it 2.5 stars.  The flavor as OK; but, the pork was tough.

Worst yet, there was a slice of bone in the dish, and I broke a corner off of one of my teeth biting into it!

So, I'll have to drop my review to 1 star as I head off to the dentist. :-(
author: Roy C.

description:
I came to Henry Hunan's with my colleagues for an lunch. This location wasn't overly full and we were seated right away. They have a counter for people to eat at but then you're stuck looking at people mooning you since the rise of low cut jeans are in. 

The food here is plentiful and delicious. It is on the greasier side so if you're on a diet, this is not the place to go. 

So you might be asking yourself - Why the two stars? The service is less than desirable and down right rude. The way these women talk about their customers and scoff at them, I couldn't believe it was truly happening. That alone will prevent me from coming back here. 

Review #10 of 2017
author: Stephanie G.

description:
Fidi and on the edge of Chi-town!

Grub, lunch spot for the stir-fried plates with rice!  Yum! 

Diana's meat pie is a signature must get.  Hot and sour soup, warms up the palate on a cold day!  Their curry beef is a saucy win over rice!  My most favorite dish is their hot and sour chicken!  It has that kick that spurs the taste buds!

This place reminds me of the song by T.I. with Keri Hilson, Got Your Back, for some odd reason. It reminds me of the good memories of being careless, young, wild, free and sheltered, I suppose.   Maybe, it's just the recent mood I am in while nom-ming away here or probably got me reflecting on appreciating what was probably all I have ever wanted, but didn't know at that time. 

Well, their food got me pricking and thinking away! 

It's homely!  I like it!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
Been going here for a while and they are one of my go to for lunch.  My friends and I are addicted to their meat pie and if we are craving for meat pie we would come here to get our meat pie fixed.  

Food: very tasty and hearty. They give big portion so be prepare to have left over.  My friends and I always get A La Carte and we would just save it for next day lunch.  its taste better the next day actually. Fair warning: most of their dishes can be really spicy, so if you can't handle spicy food, make sure you tell the waitress. 

My to go would be: Meat pie, Marty's Special, Henry's special, and combo fried rice. 
Occasionally: Beef with green beans, Mongolian beef, and kung pao chicken.  

Service: very fast and can be attentive if its not super busy.
author: Candice Y.

description:
This is one of my very favorite places for lunch in SF. I used to go into the office (instead of working from home) just so I could go to lunch at Henry's. When you go, sit at the bar and watch the ladies cook the meals one at a time, super fast, in the big woks, and notice how they send some plates up the little dumbwaiter to the upstairs dining room. 
Try the potstickers and the Kung Pao and the noodles with veggies (mainly cabbage) and pork sauce. May sound weird but it's amazing. But really everything is great.
author: Dale H.

description: Fast, seemingly good quality food at a good price. Try the Diana's Meat Pie.
author: Rob M.

description: Amazing food with a great price. Worth the wait! Call in if you're in a rush during lunch hour.
author: Maria R.

description: The best meal we had all week while visiting San Francisco! Good price, easy to order, and served fast. The meal had the right amount of spice and heat, great flavors. Highly recommended!
author: Vigil V.

description:
Best Dollar for Dollar Chinese food in The City. The exterior is sketchy the interior isn't better but the food is insane!!!

I love mah po tofu / harvest pork and have had most pork or chicken items on the menu and everything is really good (except the curry). 

They have a pork filled pancake appetizer thing that is KILLER. 

Portions are huge you will leave very satisfied.
author: Dave K.

description:
Yup two stars, why? Because this was my fifth or sixth time at this location and ab so lute ly my last. 
is the food good ? Yes, some of it is and some of it is. even great. 
The service is fng awful, they are down right fng rude and I'm over it. Blame it on a cultural difference? No way man, they don't get off that easy.

My coworkers and I used to come here a lot. They used to seek out this lady "Lulu" and try to charm her for fun because she is such a grump. They thought it was funny that she is so rude. Me, I failed to see the humor and just thought she was an arshole who hates her life.
That being said I thought she was solo on the scrappy service express. (I usually get take out).
Today I learned how awful they are to their customers. First they were bent bc I wanted a table for two for myself and my want to sit at the counter. ( the place was not busy)
I asked for a place to plug in my phone and was abruptly told "no". I told them the bathroom was out of paper and was ignored lol. I had to wave down my server who acted like she was doing me a favor to do her job.

Hot and sour soup is one of my favorites. Theirs is horrible, seriously it is chicken broth will sliced tofu (no flavor at all)
Spring rolls were totally average
Veggie chow mein was very avg (broccoli was the only veggie in it)
I actually have had great food here both today it didn't happen.

Waitress clearly was trying to rush me out before I was near being finished. Slapped the ticket on my table and took the change from my bill. Uh ya sister you are supposed to leave the change and let the patron pick it up or leave it.
I never even got a "thank you" and they don't have fortune cookies lol

Shove it up your hunan Henry's! SF is an epicenter of Asian culture I THINK I can find a better Chinese place.
author: Amy P.

description: Henry's is ligit SF Hunan have been delivering the goods for as long as I can remember
author: Austin W.

description: I placed an order to pick up for a beef and string beans rice plate for $9.80, ready in 15 minutes. It's decently priced for the Financial District. It was a little saltier than I preferred, but the meat was tender, the string beans were crunchy, and there was a good portion. It's a little spicy also for those who like a little heat. I was able to pay with a credit card, so there does not seem to be a minimum.
author: Annie L.

description: Ate dinner here as part of a large group (4 8-person tables filled) after all day business meetings.  Entire group was ordered family style.  All tables received Diana's Special Delicious Meat Pie, described as "Deep-fried thin cakes filled with meat sauce, parmesan cheese, vegetables, and onions."  My table also received hot and sour soup as an appetizer.  The soup was fabulous!  Our entree's included a green bean dish, chicken curry, steak and brocolli, kung pao chicken (mild and spicy), and a couple other dishes I don't remember.  It was all really good and I would definitely eat there again.
author: Lance B.

description: Loved the potstickers.... I was freezing in that restaurant in Sacramento St. location... even rest of the dishes ordered were too cold after coming out of the kitchen... it was like eating in a freezer
author: Carolyn C.

description: Wow--really disappointing!  I went in for a quick bite at lunch, and ordered one of the daily Rice Plate specials--Kung Pao Chicken.  Fairly common dish at many Chinese food places.  What I got was at least a full pound and a half of stir-fried ONIONS, with a few tiny pieces of obliterated chicken (I think) flesh on top.  Seriously, I tried separating out the onions from everything else, and it took up literally half of the entire plate!  I don't normally have anything against onions, mind you, but I felt really gypped here.
author: Marlin B.

description: Financial District institution for great chinese at lunch.  Best steamed dumplings in SF.  The sauce for the dumplings is addictive.  String beans and smoked ham is a classic dish.  Any kung pao dish is excellent and chicken salad is always great.
author: Bryan V.

description: I heard good things about this place and finally decide to try it out for lunch the first time as I am craving for spicy food SO MUCH. To begin with, I am a picky spicy food lover and expect a lot (maybe too much) from them. I asked for spicy, and they messed up my order and it is not spicy AT ALL. I went back to tell them it is not spicy, and they gave me some spicy sauce, the spicy sauce portion is very tiny so even with two portion, it still didn't change much of the taste. Overall I am disappointed. I don't see myself going back or recommend this place, at least not voluntarily.
author: Sophia H.

description:
In a word...terrible.  The food is full of grease, the meat is chewy, and the place itself is filthy and rundown.  One of my former bosses loved to come here because it was cheap, and that's the only thing it has going for it.  

This place epitomizes everything that's wrong with the vast majority of the Chinese food you get in SF; cheap ingredients, absence of flavor, grisly meat, and yet people rave how good it is.  Never understood why there are only a handful of decent Chinese places to eat in SF, which normally is such a "foodie" city.  I've lived in and around several cities in the U.S., and this city by far has the worst Chinese food.
author: Sean M.

description:
Interesting set up here. I think there is some sort of dorm upstairs and they share the stairway. One time we were going up the stairs and saw someone coming down with what looked like their laundry. BUT, the garlic chicken is why I keep coming back. It is so good, cheap, and the portion sizes are so generous that make this place an awesome deal for a quick lunch in the FiDi. 

I've only dat down to eat here twice. I usually just order for take out and take it back to the office. You can call ahead for picking up an they will have your order ready when you arrive. In sum, garlic chicken and the green beans are my go-tos here and they have never disappointed.
author: Thielson D.

description: This has been my long time favorite for over a decade, but sitting at the counter today it was clear they have lost their grove.  Food slow, ok, but not the same dance that has charactrrized this classic for years.
author: Steve C.

description: This place is definitely a hole in the wall and rather run down, but who cares when you're just having lunch when it's the food that matters? Get the dumplings, the noodles with meat sauce and Henry's sauce, the spicy cod fillets, and the Henry's shredded pork. People who say it's not the best Chinese food don't realize that many dishes are very authentic rather than Americanized.
author: Les N.

description: Henry's Pork Noodles with special sauce and Diana's meat pie. If you find anything this good you should eat it
author: John J.

description: Quality of food has gone down significantly. My mapo tofu was absolutely DROWNING  in oil and seemed like bottom of the barrel scraps. Informed the waitress and management about the disappointing quality and received ZERO acknowledgment. I've been a customer for years. Realizing this is a "hole in the wall" and sure, I'm not an every day customer...still very Disappointed in the level of customer service and pride in their product.
author: Julia Y.

description:
3 cheers for Henry's Hunan in their Financial District store front venue.  This venue is a small restaurant and super popular with all of San Francisco's financial district professionals who are stuck eating doughy sandwiches all week long.  

A reprieve from the ho-hum fare of so many lunch time SF Fin District venues.

My personal favorites include "Henry's Special" which is out of this world.

Their "Special" fried rice has 3 kinds of meat in it and is 100% worth the extra price from the regular fried rice.

Excellent pot stickers and egg rolls, too!

But, shhhhh, don't tell all your friends.  I still want to be able to get a table for lunch!
author: April B.

description:
I have ordered here a couple times for our office meetings. It's definitely a change from the sandwiches and salads we always have. And it's quite a delight that there's a change in our menu. I mean it's basic Chinese food. It's filling so that does the job. 

The service however is always wonderful. One of the owners knows me now by name. I give her the amount I need and what to order and she always knows how to take care of it. The delivery is always on time and provides the right amount of serving utensils. 

If your office needs catered Chinese food, order from here. It's always a hit in our office!
author: Dara S.

description:
The food here is not bad and the service is ok too. I think it's just hard for me to give this place more than 3 stars because there are so many more "better" Chinese restaurants around here. I mean after all, this place is next to China Town... I went in on a Monday afternoon for lunch. This place looks run down from the outside; it looks like you are walking in a bad neighborhood... Fences on the windows, paints chipping off.. Pretty negative vibe from the outside. There's a good picture that depicts this on this yelp page. If you scroll through the pictures, you will see what I am taking about. But once you enter, the perception changes from "What the hell is this place" to "Ahhh, another Chinese Restaurant." lol

And.... well that's pretty much it. It's another Chinese restaurant... I could see myself coming back here to eat again. Pretty cheap with few selections for the lunch special.
author: John L.

description:
Nothing special about this place whatsoever. Got takeout for lunch one day and ordered the daily special of chicken in black bean sauce. I mistakenly asked for them to make it spicy because this dish was CRAZY spicy! It basically tasted of black pepper and chili flakes. It was a struggle to eat and there was no other taste besides the spicy paste. 

Just a tip: Don't ask for them to make it spicy even if you like spicy food, I would recommend getting the spicy sauce on the side so you can actually taste the flavors of the food as well.
author: Malika R.

description: Ate here weekly for years but food and service have both deteriorated to the point that I won't go back.  Waitresses are rushed but fairly polite.  The owner and I assume her son working the cash register are the definition of caustic.  Like many in SF, I don't carry cash.  CC or ApplePay.  Don't accept any digital wallets and apparently can't accept some Visa cards.  The first time, the muppet said the charge wouldn't go through.  The next time, he argued that he had told us that Chase Sapphire Reserve cards don't work with their system and I have to pay by cash.  Yup.  Our problem, not his apparently.  Since they still swipe the cards guessing they have never upgraded their systems since the place opened in the 70's but it is somehow the customers fault, right?  And instead of just raising their prices the quality of their meat has gotten to where I wouldn't order chicken (my favorite) a 18 months ago and lately only ordered pork because their beef was so chewy and odd.  Not sure if the surly service is true for all the Henry Hunan's but sad to see a fairly consistent establishment do downhill so quickly.
author: Caliban G.

description: Henry wasn't there and they laughed when I asked to see him so that was kinda disappointing. Food was good tho.
author: Joe S.

description:
Pretty good dumplings; Big, tender, juicy, but an excessive amount of oil and soy sauce. Still, very tasty if you pat them dry first.

I also had the Kung Pao Chicken, which should've been called Kung Pao Veggies; Way too many water chestnuts and onions, and not a lot of sauce. 

There has to be better Chinese Food nearby. I mean, it's practically in China Town, right?
author: Heather A.

description: Mmhh. There are better Chinese restaurants out there. I ordered the spicy fried rice and it was very bland. The dumplings were too tick and again, under-seasoned. It is ok for a quick bite, but I wouldn't say it is one of my regular places to eat during lunch. I think it's big brother, on Natoma does a better job.
author: Carla L.

description:
Good "Chinese" food at a reasonable price.  Restaurant is very unassuming and despite the small appearance, features a large upstairs dining room with two large round tables that can easily fit 10 each.  

Food is slightly greasy and lacks the complex flavors (particularly spices) of Hunan food.  In fact, most dishes are distinctly not Hunanese (and many are not even Chinese).  Maybe the fact it's "Henry's Hunan" should have been the first clue.
author: Greg B.

description: Awesome.  Best Hunan Chinese food I've ever had. Sit at the bar and watch them wok your food.
author: Diane F.

description: I ordered Hunan chicken over rice. The food was greasy and the rice was old. You can tell that. The chicken was tasteless. Saw the cook double dipping on peanuts that's there for cooking. Not recommended.
author: Shivaji D.

description:
Ordered Kung pro chicken with rice.
Very Oily Chinese food... Not spicy.
Had better food elsewhere : ( 
I heard great things, but disappointed...
author: Sunny S.

description: this used to be my favorite spot for lunch. something has changed here. seems like the owner changed? food definitely changed. quality gone way down. dishes are not the same. why mess with good things? please bring back old chefs back.
author: Michael O.

description:
Love Henrys...
Such nice people.
They make my orders extra spicy the way I enjoy it best.
Friendly , not bad prices and always leave more than happy. 
Thanks Hunan happiness
author: Connie B.

description:
In the past year since Linda retired, they have downgraded the quality of meat they use.  That's soooo disappointing - the chicken is now poor quality.  Stick to their location on Church St. instead - they do it right.  5 Stars for Church St. location.

Please please upgrade your the quality of your dishes back to the way they were!
author: Brian S.

description: When coming here for Chinese food, you have to keep in mind the style of cooking it is. This is not the typical saucy, less oily Cantonese food you're probably accustomed to in this area. As their name suggests, this is Hunan cooking which is more oily and the spicy level is not as hot as Szechuan cooking. With that being said, Henry Hunan's serves pretty good Hunan Chinese food. My office will occasionally order take out from here if we want to change it up. The Spicy Rock Cod, Chicken Chow Mein, Marty's Special, Kung Pao Chicken, Shrimp with Tofu (has ground meat unless you specify not to add) and the Pork Dumplings are our favorites. If I could just eat Dumplings and Chow Mein, I would be set but that doesn't bold well for a low carb diet. For the vegetarian selections, we get the Egg Rolls, Country Vegetables which has some tofu and clear noodles, Vegetable Chow Mein and Stir Fried Green Beans. If you don't want any spicy or hot, their menu does offer a few dishes. They use a lot of garlic in certain dishes so I hope you like garlic. As I mentioned, this type of cooking is oily so don't come to this type of place wondering why. It's the spicy oil they use and the way it is cooked in the wok that causes it to be more oily than other types of Chinese food. It's not what you'd call "stir fry". I only know the term for this style of cooking in Chinese and I don't have a translation. This location is small but it's open really early so that's a plus for those working an earlier shift or those wanting to drop off an order earlier for pick up at 11:45pm. Our order is always on time and correct. The service is friendly and efficient.
author: Jen L.

description: I never venture far outside of the Financial District during the week but this place was well worth the Lyft fair. I met my family here for dinner before a nearby concert. Things seemed to move a little slow considering that the restaurant wasn't super busy but I also appreciated that each dish came out on it's own or with an appropriate pairing so that we didn't have everything on the table at once. Overall, pretty good experience and the food tasted incredible so I would definitely go back.
author: Stephanie D.

description: Henry Hunan is my go to place during the week when I don't know what I want to eat for lunch. The Kung Pao Chicken over rice never lets me down. Good food, large portion, under $10... Can't go wrong!
author: Michelle E.

description:
Oh, how I miss this option.  When I lived and worked nearby we ate lunch here too often.  It became a source of pounds and inches.

This is a dive with abrupt service and amazing food.
author: Phil G.

description:
2.5 stars. 

This is one of those places where you don't want to touch anything because it's either greasy or sticky... however, that's how most Chinese restaurants are, no? 

Once you get over that feeling... the portions are large, and the prices are decent for being in the FiDi. 

The food is super greasy, so if that is what you want, you will definitely get that here. 

The first time I came here I cracked up at the menu because there's a section for "spicy, but not hot" dishes. What does that even mean?! I mean I get it but not really... I normally order the Kung Pao Beef, extra spicy, rice plate. Most of their entrees can be made into rice plates for a little less. I usually get the rice plate if I don't want leftovers (but it is still a large portion). If you order the entree, with a side of rice, it's definitely enough for a next day meal. 

I need to try that meat pie that people come here for, maybe that's their saving grace. Otherwise, it's just another Chinese restaurant among many. Nothing special, especially because it's inconsistent with spice levels. I want SPICY, and only once when I asked for extra spicy did I really get it.

Oh, and they actually have daily specials for a lower price. Not too bad! I just know the Kung Pao Beef is the special for Thursday for (I think) $7.50.
author: Jeannie L.

description:
I'm not entirely sure if this is the one that I go to in the Financial District, but the location looks right.

I'm really big on cheap, filling, yummy lunches when I'm at work. And Henry's Hunan provides such a different fare from the usual soups, sandwiches and salads that are prevalent in the area.

While Hunan fare is typically super spicy, Henry's offers you the option to make their food mild which is a godsend for me because I can't handle the heat :( I definitely recommend their eggplant or their meat pie! It's amazing.

They are more of a sit-down meal choice than a grab-and-go place, so make sure you're able to enjoy the entirety of your lunch hour here or else you're going to find yourself a little squeezed for time. Sadly, I'm usually in more of a grab-and-go mindset than a sit-down-and-nom mindset so I don't get to come here too often. But it's okay, because then coming here is more of a treat!
author: Anna W.

description: My coworkers really love this place so I've been a handful of times with them. As everyone here on Yelp recommends, get the meat pie. Never in my life have I heard of meat pie, but it's more or less ground beef between two green onion pancakes. The green onion pancakes are one of the worst I've ever had, but in the meat pie, they are spectacular. For the price, you're getting better food than you'd get at Panda Express, but the food is definitely on the salty side, so be ready to have a lot of water ready.
author: Austin W.

description:
They use a lot of "hot bean sauce" in their stir fry dishes which I personally did not really enjoy.  It does add a lot of extra savory flavor but makes everything it's in really salty.  

Price was cheap, but being right next to Chinatown, I wouldn't go there again.  
Also, the food isn't THAT spicy.  Or maybe I just like really spicy food.  My friends were talking smack about how spicy the food was but it wasn't all that hot.
author: Bryan P.

description:
The guy who took my to go order is as nice on the phone as he is in person. Food comes out fast. When they said 10-15 minutes, it really did. 

We had the ham and veggies, shrimp and bean curd, chicken chow mein and Marty's Special. Overall, everything was too salty for our palettes. Good flavors but daaaamn I hella needed a boatload of water during and after my lunch.
author: Julie L.

description:
Rather average all around. We occasionally order lunch for pickup here at work. The portions are very, very generous and the prices are low.

Overall, the food is very, very greasy. Plenty of flavors, but overwhelming at times. Expect the spicy dishes to be spicy - and I mean very spicy! 

Of note, tho, are the potstickers. They come in this vinegar soy sauce mix that is divine. Definitely recommended with any order here. I've also heard great things about the Marty's Special, tho not tried it myself.

Will say that it is very convenient and efficient for pick up. A solid backup choice or standby for food at work.
author: Patrick O.

description: My coworkers decided to have a "to-go" party. We decided to order 6 different plates. Each of them were really good, had its own taste except they were all spicy, so they tasted the same.  Come by and order the Chicken Chow Mein, Kung Pow Chicken, Marty's Special!! It's worth the price because they give you a lot of food (BIG PORTIONS!)
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
Great food and the service was very quick and efficient. We sat upstairs which was a little warm, but it was an unusually warm day in the city so it was a bit understandable. 

My only complaint would be that we ordered three dishes and soup, but the dishes came out one at a time instead of at the same time so we actually forgot that we had more food coming and were almost done eating when the last dish came out.

Otherwise it is a good stop in fi di.
author: Jennifer S. C.

description:
Eating at a Chinese restaurant with an ABC is loads of fun. A coworker of mine grew up in the Chinese restaurant business, and her father still owns a place in Los Angeles. So I always enjoy hearing her play-by-play at Henry's, usually regarding the service:

1) they won't give us chopsticks unless we ask because you're white (she was right)

2) they won't give us hot tea unless you ask (again, right)

3) they won't give us to-go boxes unless you ask (uncanny!)

4) they won't tell you that you have to pay downstairs; they'll walk by again and again, looking at your credit card and not say a word (damn her!)

I'm used to brusque and indifferent service at many Chinese restaurants, but sometimes this place tests my patience. And it's not all of the time; just with certain servers. Thankfully, their food is pretty good so we keep going back.
author: Jeff R.

description: The pork fried rice was flavorful and had the right amount of heat.  Make sure to eat your take out while its still warm or you'll end up with all the grease at the bottom.
author: Jo B.

description: The Kung Pao chicken was delicious and service was friendly and fast. A friend recommended this and I wasn't disappointed.
author: Dan W.

description: Big change since they switched to new ownership, they raised the prices and shrunk the portion.  It used to be great.  Now it is not as crowded as it used to and the only change they made was to raise prices while reducing portion sizes.
author: Laurent G.

description:
Spicy! But tastes good - so you can't stop eating even as your mouth burns more and more..

The water tastes bad there. 

Would recommend: Kung pao chicken.
author: Gee H.

description:
The first time i went there, i had fried rice which was really just so-so.

The second time... many moons later ... i decided to call for a take-out after reading raving reviews about the meat pie.

I must say, it wasn't disappointing. The crust has a croissant, thin, crispy, buttery layers. It wasn't a real pie-pie when you can hold it and eat it. Imagine two layers of burrito-like wraps but opened up. First layer sits in the box as the meat filing is generously spread across layer one, followed by another generous layer of shaved fresh lettuce. The final 'layer' then goes on top. It's cut into quadrants, so if you picked it up, some meat could fall out. I found having a fork+knife handy.

Overall, i would eat it again, only issue with it is the MSG. It's not swimming in MSG but after the meal you can feel the side effects of MSG. 

I think i will still return to try other dishes.

The shop is really small and packed, so it gets noisy in there.
author: Smo S.

description:
Maybe Tim Burton can make another version of "Sweeney Todd" with Diana's Meat Pie, and Henry can sing some Sondheim ...and then all would be right with the world, don't you think? 

There is something reassuring about seeing the red sign for Henry's Hunan, as I have been a semi-loyal customer for years. When I was an innocent babe in the big, bad corporate jungle of this city, I used to go to either the Sansome or the Natoma location to get a wedge of the Diana's Meat Pie, a heaping helping of Henry's Special, a fiery mouthful of Kung Pao Shrimp, or the cooling peanutty goodness of the Chicken Salad. Sure it was a ton of food, but I was ready, willing and able to cope with indigestion back in the office.

My cholesterol count doesn't allow me such indulgences anymore, but I still have a craving for Henry's now and then. This location is a lot smaller and probably the most low profile of the four locations in the city, probably because they're not open on weekends or in the evening. Make no mistake that this is a lunchtime hub of activity for the working drones in the area, and this drone is just a few steps away from the place. Even with a second floor of tables a precarious climb away, it still gets packed pretty fast at noon. I usually try to come after the rush if I'm not drowning in afternoon meetings.

What does strike me most is how much friendlier they are here versus the other locations, especially the semi-surly staff at Natoma, and I've been trying other things on the menu. Recently, I went for the $6.25 Noodles with Pork Meat and Special Hunan Sauce. Honestly, it was like a bowl of Chef-Boyardee Beefaroni, but it did hit the spot in a greasy sort of way. With a vegetarian colleague, I went for the meatless version of the $7.50 Sauteed Eggplant and the same-priced Country-Style Vegetables. Both were tasty and more than filling. This ain't no Michelin Guide three-star destination...it's just Henry.

FOOD - 3 stars...dependable, big portions and sometimes even tasty
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...the most claustrophobic of the Henrys
SERVICE - 4 stars...the friendliest of the Henrys
TOTAL - 3 stars...feels like an old shoe...luckily it doesn't taste like one
author: Ed U.

description:
I don't always eat Chinese food but when I do, I eat Henry's Hunan.

Place looks like it was decorated in the 1980s with hand me down furniture from an elementary school in Hunter's Point.  However, the food is really solid.  This is the place to see and be seen in the financial district for Chinese.
author: Chris F.

description:
Henry's Hunan Sacramento St. 

A few years ago I absolutely loved this restaurant. The customer service was decent and the food was spicy and hella good. As of late, I always walk away greatly disappointed. The food still taste good, however, when I order any dish that has meat or seafood in it. They give me very little seafood or chicken every time. The shrimp is cut in half and perhaps thirds and the chicken is diced up. My last two orders were Spicy Garlic Chicken and Henry Hunan's Special Seafood dish. I got 95% vegetables on each dish. When I asked them " if I can get my order to look like the picture" they have posted, the host said "give her back her money".
author: SulaKongo K.

description: Okay, I have to upgrade this review because over the years I keep coming back to this place because I really really like the food.  Sometimes they do not understand what I order so I get what I get, and it turns out I always  like it! The service has not changed, really, but I am used to it now.  Also I have to mention that all the other Hunans around the city are DELICIOUS. So that, four stars - flavor wins.
author: Buena M.

description: Really good food and really good customer service.  Very friendly staff and the food was delicious!  Definitely will go back when I'm in the city again.
author: Neil K.

description:
I'm updating my review. I went today for the first time in a long time. I had been once already earlier this year when I learned that Linda had retired and 90% of the staff had changed. At that time the food still tasted the same.
Today however it was apparent things were different. 
My default order of Kung Pao chicken rice plate was almost all rice with a little bit of kung pao on top. I was pretty shocked. The taste was also not the same. I remember crunchy peanuts and the smoky, briney, spicey goodness that it was. This was not the same dish.
I ordered dumplings since I was not satisfied with the smaller portion and they were also just ok. I remember these used to be insanely great.
I checked Yelp and sure enough my findings are spot on, in line with what others are saying. Too bad, I had gone to this location for 20 years and knew the entire staff well. I won't be returning here anymore. 
A note to mgmt: don't scrimp on the small amount of money saved by downgrading the quality of the ingredients. This place was made famous because the food was great. When you make a change, especially one that introduces inferior ingredients, people will notice. Sure, enough people will probably still come in to keep the lights on, but eventually this may change as word gets out.
author: Matt H.

description: This was my go-to place for a quick take-a-way lunch because it is very near my office in the Financial District. The food isn't gourmet, but it does the trick... until today! So I called in to place a take-a-way order and asked if they would only give me  1/2 the rice for the lunch special I wanted.  I was rudely told no. I tried to explain that I did not expect to pay less and that I didn't want more of the main dish, just less rice. I asked if they could put the rice in a separate container and I was rudely told only if I paid the dinner price instead of the lunch special price.  Then the guy I was speaking to hung up the phone. It is sad that this guy would turn away a customer who was asking to pay the same price and walk out with less food/product... I expect with a business sense like this it's only a matter of time until the space is available for rent.
author: Yosi W.

description: Yummy food!  Took a couple coworkers here for lunch and they fell in love.  We ended up eating upstairs and the food came up quickly.  One of them said it was the best Chinese chicken salad she had ever had.  The chicken fried rice was great.  My friend also loves the Mongolian beef over rice.  I've never had a bad meal here.
author: Marylouise R.

description: Kind of tucked away on Sacramento Street. Always busy for lunch. Really enjoyed the spicy food we had here. Huge portions too.
author: Karlijn V.

description:
Had lunch there today!

Fantastic meat pies, make sure you order one for the table. They make a great starter, and you absolutely won't be sorry. The dishes are spicy, the service is friendly, and the wait time is minimal. I also appreciate that they pay attention to your water glass and make sure to refill when you are low. 

Great lunch option for those in CBD, just don't be surprised if the place is full!
author: Peter C.

description:
Henry's on Sacramento Street used to be one of my favorite restaurants for Hunan cooking. In the last year or so it has changed quite a bit. I was disappointed with the hot and sour beef which had very little beef and mostly onions. I ordered it hot which was okay but it wasn't sour. I think they forgot the vinegar. They need to give the cooks some lessons from the cooks at the Natoma Street restaurant.  
This location no longer cooks the way the original Henry's Hunan.. I do not think I will go back.
author: Diner D.

description: Came here to try a few of their top dishes, but I didn't like the flavor. Honestly, the food wasn't bad, but I prefer Young's Cafe down the street.
author: John D.

description:
Food is always fresh, and the quality is good, but really most sauces taste the same. 

My favorite is the spicy fish and tofu over rice. I usually ask them to skip the soy sauce so it is not as salty.

The line of cooks are all women, which is awesome.
author: L S.

description:
We went for lunch. Ordered food to share.

Hot and Sour Soup was good. Not as spicy as I expected.

Marty's Special - A combination dish with ham and chicken. We ordered spicy. It was very good. The mix of the ham and chicken worked very well.

Hunan Shrimp - A shrimp and veggies dish. It was also very good.

All of the dishes were above average. I will definitely be returning. 

Very basic ambiance.  Service was quick.
author: Mark D.

description: Their best dishes are hot & sour chicken, hot & sour soup, hot & sour beef, chicken salad, and diana's special meat pie.  I've been eating at hunan since i was 15.  They do not disappoint. Love Hunan.
author: Hyla S.

description:
Fresh, hot and delicious! Spicy crack is what my "Henry's buddy" and I call it.  You will find us here twice a week, every week.  Current fav dish is Velvet Chicken-spicy.  The flavors are very intense, bland food it is not. Like most, I agree the Meat Pie is a must. 
Try not to sit upstairs unless you have to, they tend to forget about you once in a while.  Don't bother complaining either for the wait on occasion.  You will not like the answer, once we were told hungry people are very grumpy, so basically tough cookies for the wait.  Besides, Linda is busy counting her money at the register so don't bother her. Just be patient, don't come here if you're in a hurry. It will be worth the wait.  Even so, I love this place, because it's just that good. The waiters are nice and will remember you by name.  The lunch specials for $7.00 rock.
author: Sara S.

description:
I had a quick lunch with my Mom. The service is quick and cheerful. Upon entering, everything smelled and looked great. I had high hopes about it being real Hunanese food and I was not disappointed. Beautiful flavors and textures. We ordered Eggplant cooked in the style of hot pot (I forget the actual dish name) and Pork with Cabbage (same, re the name, something like "homestyle pork").

I plan on returning with a large group so we can order and try more dishes!

They also have a great counter at the back if you are eating solo and you can watch them cook!
author: Heather P.

description: Came here for lunch and there was seating available. Food was fast and delicious. Slightly greasy but worth it.
author: Mel P.

description: OK to good food, fast service if you don't run straight into the rush.
author: drew n.

description: I came here during a lunch break with a really good friend of mine - he recommended the place.  There's two levels and it gets really busy during lunchtime.  We ordered three dishes but I only remember one - the fried fish!  It was really crispy and tasty and not too heavy.  And it's cheap!
author: Linh V.

description:
five star for Linda, she is AH-mazing. She remembers everyone. 
I love their green bean chicken with extra spicy sauce. This one is great even when you take it to go.
But Linda and the guy that work there, they are amazing
author: fenny g.

description:
You're testing my patience.
I understand it's a Chinese restaurant, so I don't expect great service.
I just want my freakin' food, which is always good.

There were three of us for lunch.  And two tables after us were seated...8+ per table.  

They ordered after we did, they were being served their entrees left and right.  We had a bowl of rice on the table, that was hot at some point, then one entree came, and then 15 minutes later mine came, and another 10 minutes passed before we finally asked them about the third entree.  

The server said this "all of you (the five tables including us) sat down at the same time..." O.O are you serious?! Seriously arguing with us?

I hear her in Chinese, "Where is the orange chicken? I think we forgot to order it!!"  Nice, lady.  (This is the same Rice lady from my last review, btw.)

Yeah, we're not eating there for sit-down at lunch any more (especially not upstairs).  It doesn't matter on the timing.  And no, we did not tip them.
author: Fannie S.

description: The kung pao shrimp at this place is fantastic. As are the beef and green beans. You pretty much can't go wrong with any meal but those are two of my favs.
author: Bud H.

description: I must have ordered the wrong thing. My coworker and I originally were planning on having Japanese food next door but the line was so long and we were starving so Chinese it was. We both ordered the garlic chicken dish. It was very bland but the ingredients that were used seemed of higher quality than most of the Chinese places around this area. I may be back and order something different but it's not likely.
author: Zannie S.

description:
This used to be my go-to Chinese spot in the fi-di.  I recently got lunch here and was very sad to see that the wonderful lady who worked the counter for the past 20 years retired.  Coincidentally(?), they were also out of soy sauce packets.

She was a real delight and the place does not have the same vibe anymore.  There was another lady who had been working there for a very long time whom I also did not see on my recent visit.  Lots of new faces and the food was a little under done.

I'm not writing them off and will report back after my next visit.

:(
author: Otto D.

description: The food is insanely good. The Mongolian Beef is one of the tastiest Chinese dishes I've ever had in my life, and I've lived in China for several years. Interior is drab, to put it lightly, but it adds to the mystique of being surprised by a hole in the wall.
author: Neal F.

description: Returned again after a long layoff.  Got the Kung Pao again at rating stays the same.  Cost eating in was $9 with tip.  Fair price for amount and quality.  Nice to sit at counter and watch the wok action.   It's not on the menu, but you can specify your chicken to be kung pao for the lunch rice plate.
author: Marc S.

description:
How is it that most of the Chinese food in Chinatown is gross and Americanized? Granted this is financial district, however why anyone attempts chinatown is beyond us.

Henry's is hands down like been in Hong Kong! We order everything spicy... Still have yet to have an average meal. Staff is so friendly and remembers you immediately. Love the beef with string beans, however the entire menu is solid.

Huge fans!!!
author: SF U.

description:
Great weekday lunch spot: food is fast, service is prompt, lots of regulars. The place looks like a dive - minimal decor, almost no street facing attractive features. But inside, it is a tasty different story. There is a bar if you want to eat as 1 or 2, and many tables, on the ground floor, and apparently, on the 2 floors above.
Try the meat pie, and the orange chicken, and there was a tasty bean curd/tofu dish.
author: Erik Y.

description: Great authencity. I had shrimp with tofu and some other dish and was great value for money.  They cook the food right in front of you which I guess adds to the appeal.  Its on the hot side for taste and a lot of the deep fried stuff like tofu and chicken are all pre-fried and are in big bags of plastic.  Thats the reality of chinese wok cooking.
author: Manny B.

description:
On one of my last few lunch dates with my colleagues, I suggested Henry's Hunan.  I was introduced to this chain by my previous employer who absolutely loved Henry's and ordered from there on a weekly basis.

We head over to the Sacramento location and find a few empty tables upstairs during their busy lunch rush.  This location isn't quite as nice as some of their other ones, but it'll do.

For the four of us, we ordered Shrimp Chow Mein ($8.50), Chicken with Black Bean Sauce ($8.75), Beef with Broccoli ($8.75), Dry Sauteed String Beans ($8.25), and one of their specials of the day - Fish Fillet.  And of course, a pot of steamed white rice.

Service is typical of the Chinese restaurant.  Just plain fast and efficient.  No frills here.  We were all surprised with how quickly our orders came out and we were woofing it down quick.  Everyone was pleased with all the food we got and we had minimal leftovers, only because we had ordered so much.  My favorite has been the Chicken with Black Bean Sauce and the Dry Sauteed String Beans.  They do them right here.  I've also had their Dumplings ($4.50) too.  

Yes, it's pretty pricey, too pricey for what I would normally pay for Chinese food, that's for sure.  But when it comes down to it, it's the kind of food that the masses enjoy from all ethnic backgrounds and usually has a little kick in it as well.  

Solid 3.5 stars.
author: Teri C.

description:
If you're 1) drunk, hungry, and in the area, 2) have friends who might cringe from excessively sticky "cleaned" tables a few blocks over in C-Town, and 3) don't have your own private driver, by all means enter, this will probably satisfy your party's hunger without having to worry about death threats.

I've been here a bunch of times. Only for business dinners so price doesn't factor 'cause I don't know how much the bill was! Usually higher paid muck-ity mucks ordered as well "charging it" so maybe I didn't get the "good stuff". Enough excuses?!? ;-)

OK, I did pay a little attention to the food and it was average. Good, but not great. No one spit out a bite or two while finishing the rest (1-2 stars) or got violently ill (should be 0 or less stars, but hey, Yelp! has a limited range.), or went into anaphylactic shock (-1x10^999999999999 stars).

Likewise, no one said that they need to eat here as often as possible and sing it's praises to every passer-by (5 stars) or even that they'd recommend it to friends, if asked (3+ to 4 stars). Most agreed it was decent with no standout or "Wow" factor so please don't ask me what I ate . . . yes, it was that memorable.

Well there it is. 3 stars

Add to that, I enjoyed the food (everything tastes better when it's free), but haven't come here whilst paying my own way after having free samples numerous times. What does that say?

OK, 3 stars. Sorry for repeating myself!! :(
author: Andrew C.

description: Consistently great fresh flavors. Very satisfying; very reasonable pricing. Truly a San Francisco China Town landmark!
author: Hank W.

description:
This place is so overrated! The kung pao chicken just tastes... odd. I don't get it. Is everyone a disciple of that online guy who ate every dish on the menu and then chronicled it?
http://kingofusagoestojapan.com/henrys/
author: Kathleen M.

description: Looking for a go-to Chinese place in the FiDi, I found Henry's Hunan! I've ordered 5 different items on its lunch special menu, all of which I would order again except maybe Hot and Sour Beef (just a little weird to me). The food can be pretty spicy, so be warned; however, they can tone down the spiciness by using more black bean sauce if needed (not advisable in my opinion). The $7.90 lunch specials are a great deal, so don't be discouraged by the sight of a "small" to-go box as the portions of meat/rice are actually very filling. Finally, you can order anything you want on the lunch special menu regardless of the day, which is awesome! I would definitely recommend Kung Pao Beef/Chicken, Marty's Special, Harvest Pork, and Chicken w/ String Beans. I would definitely recommend Henry's Hunan to anybody looking for some spicy Chinese food!
author: Andrew Y.

description: This is such a rad rad place. So many good things on the menu. Spicy yumminess. Bustling lunch scene. Great meat pie. I'll be back again and again. How did I ever NOT work in downtown SF?
author: Andrew K.

description:
The tea tastes like black pepper. This can be attributed to one of three things:

1. There is black pepper in the tea.
2. The cups are washed along with dishes that are covered in peppery grease.
3. The tea is washing the peppery grease from my teeth.

The food is OK!
author: Kevin L.

description:
A must for us, when in the bay area. 

Food:
Delicious. I haven't been disappointed yet. They use the smaller shrimp in most of the shrimp dishes, not a negative or knock, but rather you get plenty of them in your dish.

Environment:
A definite dive, but this is the nostalgic charm of the joint. Rubbing elbows with natives and an ear shot of everyone's conversation. It might bug some, but I could careless.

Price:
For a family of four, we walk out with about a $70 - 80 of damage. We eat family style and share about 5 to 6 dishes.  

Parking:
Public structure parking, good luck finding street parking. I'd recommend parking near Union Square, if visiting the City, and walking from there through Chinatown. The walk will get your appetite going, and afterwards walk the meal off back to Union Square while doing some shopping.

Bon Appetit!
author: Rick A.

description:
This is the best now of the Henry's bunch of Hunan style restaurants in SF and most like the original (gone since '89 earthquake) on Kearny.  The foods seems fresher - probably because of the high lunchtime turnover and they don't do dinner here).

Best place to sit: behind the counter where you can witness all the hot magical cooking by 3-4 women.

My recommendations on what to get: the original Hunan type dishes back from the day the New Yorker matter-of-factly called it "the best Chinese restaurant in the world."

Dumplings (always boiled)
Onion Cakes (best in town and here before others arrived)
Henry's Special (home smoked ham and chicken with bean sauce)
Shrimp/Scallop/Chicken with bean sauce
Harvest Pork (their version of twice cooked pork)
Ground pork over noodles
Ma Po Tufo (with or without ground pork)
Hot n Sour beef
Hunan spare ribs
Garlic Chicken ("the" non-hot dish!!!!!)

That's about it folks, stick to the originals if you want something the original authentic Henry style Hunan, the first one in the country.

The other stuff (traditional stuff) is good but to me they are added on to please the take-out crowd and that's fine as well.
author: John P.

description: My family has been eating here since I was small child. We're not Chinese so maybe our opinion on Chinese food isn't as important as the reviewer's who say "I'm Chinese, so I know...." but this place is the best. Despite close to 30 years of eating here, I haven't tried that many things.That's because when you're here you have to get the Diana's Special, The Hot and Sour beef, the henry special, and the chinese chicken salad and then you're pretty much full. They're really nice people too. They always recognize my dad and brother who worked in the financial district and one time I brought a date here and (not that it's a great place to bring a date) and they recognized me and gave her a Hunan mug! I felt legit. We live in the East Bay, but have probably had more family meals from Hunan than anywhere else, that says something.
author: Michael C.

description:
ordered to go kungpao  chicken lunch portion. mostly rice, good spice. easy to find. will take credit card for s
$10 purchase. maybe 10 tables. 2blocks from Grant.
author: T N.

description: I really like this place.  Old school, delicious, prices are pretty good too.  I got the Marty's Special.  Really good dish with chicken, veggies and smoked ham.  Right around (I think under) $10 and gave me enough food for 2 days.  I will definitely go back.
author: Chris R.

description:
If you like onions, onions and more onions with a few peppers thrown in then this is the place for you.  It isn't good food.  It isn't gourmet.  It all tastes basically the same.  I go here occasionally because it is close to the office.  Otherwise I wouldn't bother.

I hate how they mix tables here without care, or asking.  I don't mind a communal table depending on my mood, but shoving me to one without my consent is NOT OK.

Service here is deplorable. Food arrives in shifts and it takes FOREVER to get anything you request as an extra.
author: Katharine A.

description:
They have a yelp sticker on their door. This makes me wonder about those "people love us on yelp" stickers and who had the not-so-brilliant idea to leave off the date. I think this one may be outdated. 

While I give props to two of the friendliest folks i've come across, the food was super greasy and the meat was like bits of fat with sauce. I ended up feeling really blah after and if i'm gonna feel like that I want to have eaten like a giant cookie so it's worth it.
author: Nikki M.

description: Tip top Hunan.  My top selections are the hot and spicy fish, the chinese chicken salad, dumplings and meat pie.  If you ask nicely they will do 1/2 orders of appetizers.  Food is great, staff is great, decor is more than a little dated.
author: Eric W.

description: Oh my my my.  My co-worker had turned me onto to their dumplings.  Now its a rainy day must.  Which so far this year has been often & of course I don't mind.  Since then Henry's has been the place for my 1st attempts at Chinese -American dishes, as in mongolian beef & kung pao chicken.  I can't really compare them to anywhere else since I've never had either dish before.  But I can see they werent too bad.  I love spicy heat & they both had an enjoyable kick.  I'd definitely explore their menu a little furthur.
author: Stephanie D.

description: The best Chinese food on the planet. Try Meat pie, harvest pork, hot & sour beef. Nobody makes it like the place on Natomas in San Francisco.
author: Kevin A.

description: Just pretty good. What! No fortune cookie!!
author: Rosemarie H.

description: The food was very good.  I had the Hunan Shrimp and it was excellent. The problem I have with Henry's Hunan is that it appeared dirty to me.  They smash you in like sardines because it's the city and they have to make good use of the space. I get that! But I don't get a place that looks dirty.  They are also cheap with their ice! It's unbelievable. How much is ice??? They act like it's a precious commodity.
author: Sandra P.

description:
I love this place, I eat there often.

Try number 51, the Broccoli with Oyster Sauce, and number 5, the Five Spiced Beef.  Delicious.  The shredded potato with vegetables is excellent too.

I like the spicy red oil that is not sweet that one finds in several dishes.  I have spent a lot of time in China and I understand how serious they are about quality, and my opinion is that Henry's has it going on.  Fresh ingredients, you can taste all the flavors, excellent preparation.  I think this restaurant deserves five stars.

The food is good for you.  You feel good after eating there, not loaded down.

It is jam packed sometimes, and so you might have to wait.  But that is a sign that Henry's is that good.

I ordered enough food for 18 people for one of my classes, all kinds of dishes, recently, and everyone loved it.  I walked in to pick it up and they had totally forgotten even though I had already paid.  No problem, they got busy and whipped it all up pretty fast.  Sometimes the place is a madhouse.

Henry's is high quality genuine Hunan, and it is a treat to go there.
author: Nemo O.

description:
I eat take-out quite a lot from here for lunch. I tried a few items, ja ja mein, kao pou chicken over rice, ma po tufu over rice, and hot/sour chicken over rice. Everything is alright, but I love that hot and sour chicken over rice. 9/10 times i would order that hot and sour chicken over rice. 

Don't know why, but I love that sour and spicy taste. It also large as hell, I get so full from eating 1 order.

Oh, it takes a while for them to cook the order. Usually I leave the office 15-20 minutes after ordering over the phone and sometimes I would still have to wait for it.... I don't understand, but at least it's cooked to order.
author: Loi L.

description:
I came here for lunch on a weekday afternoon but since I was in a large group we decided to order family style and not the lunch specials.  We ordered the infamous meat pie for the appetizer and since I normally love authentic Chinese food, I have to say this tasted more like a Taco Bell gordita than typical Chinese appetizers.  Even though it wasn't necessarily Chinese, it still tasted good.

We also ordered the orange chicken, kung pao chicken, eggplant, the assorted bean curd and vegetables, the cod, and the string beans with beef.

The two dishes that really stood out to me of our selection was the assorted bean curd and the cod.  Even though the bean curd was a bit salty, I loved how colorful it was and it is an extremely good vegetarian dish.  The cod was also delicious- nice and spicy and the portions were very generous.  

The orange chicken was not very good, I think the one at Panda Express tastes better.  The eggplant was not as cooked as I would have liked.  The string beans with beef dish was pretty solid and the same with the kung pao chicken.

Overall, I would come back here to eat since I work near here!
author: Rachel L.

description:
Got some take out here for lunch. Meat pie is not Chinese at all, but it is tasty all the same. Love the pot stickers, large helpings of ground meat in the little packages. They are 2-3 bites each. Not so enamored with their egg rolls. Small and too cooked to taste anything. And finally, tried the ham and green beans. Woof.  As in bad woof. So so salty I couldn't eat more than the first piece. If you like jerky levels of salt, by all means try this dish. 

I couldn't do it though.
author: Alice K.

description: No frills, but sincerely really good. My coworker had me order the mapo tofu...I hate tofu, but this converted me. It was amazing. Dumplings and the eggplant with meat sauce were also delicious.
author: Charlie F.

description:
for the first time in forever I had a sit down at Henry's Hunan.  Normally for the take out, they get a 5.  good sized portions, it's quick, and cheep.  they drop to 3 stars if you eat in, poor service, dirty flat ware, and no beverage refills.

since I get take out 95% of the time, I'll go with a 4 star.
author: Pablo E.

description: Hmmm. One of my favorite places.  But the hostess/cashier was clipping her fingernails in the dining room during lunch. The pinging sound of sharp clippers chopping nails while I was eating my kung pao was just a bit unappetizing.
author: Eric P.

description:
I've been a fan of Henry's for a long time - and am now fortunate enough to be in the city regularly so I can eat there more often.

If you're looking for some great spicy food, you'll enjoy this.  The ambiance leaves something to be desired - but I like that there's an open kitchen so you can see what's going on.  

There are rice-plate specials every day, which are perfect for lunch.  I love the hot and sour beef.  I'm also a big fan of the meat pie (and for me, it's best with a bunch of extra hot oil).  

Bring a colleague (not a date) and enjoy!
author: S P.

description:
If this were Zagat, I'd be able to qualify my review a bit more. Like, "4 for the food, 3 for the service, 1 for the atmosphere." But I get only one choice. And since I only really care about the food, I'll stick with four.

Few Chinese restaurants do a better job of combining awesome food with rock-bottom prices. They'll turn anything on the menu into a rice plate for lunch, averaging around $7 for the meal. And the flavors are specifically Hunan: bold, spicy, simple and rustic: hot chili peppers, garlic, vinegar  and meat take center stage.

My favorites: hot and sour beef; dumplings (a meal at $4.25), and Henry's Special (chicken, scallops and shrimp in chili and black bean sauce).
author: Carl L.

description: Dropped in on a random lunch to see how another hole-in-the-wall fared.  I went for some kung pao shrimp and my boy grabbed a chicken dish that now escapes me.  It was nothing memorable.  I remember that.  The food is ok, nothing to boast.  The service and size of the place is where it falls.  It is SF, and it is a hole-in-the-wall, but it's still unsatisfying when you have to make sure you're literally not bumping elbows with another guest who isn't part of your party sharing a table with you.  I wouldn't recommend this place to anyone and that's what any restaurant really comes down to.
author: Nick J.

description:
The food is ok, but the slow service is really it's death knell, as far as I am concerned. I'm used to bad service at Chinese restaurants (it's in our DNA or something), but slow? All in all, spent about an hour at lunch, and all I got were noodles (smoke ham chow mein), which I got about 20 minutes after others in my party got their food.

The food is not bad. At least they are consistent about that (although they are likewise consistent with their atrocious wait times).
author: B Y.

description:
Definitely a fun lunch. When it comes the sticky-sweet deliciousness of American-Chinese food, Henry's comes to mind. The atmosphere feels so odd though. Maybe it's the folding tables, or the strangely plush pile carpet upstairs, but anyway it totally feels like you're dining in what used to be someone's apartment. 

Aside from the functional decor, the food is everything you could look for in this curious genre of cusine. Big bowls of steaming rice, dishes glistening with savory sauces (though they could be spicier), those rich comforting flavors your brain has just no defense against.  Yeah, pita stuffed with micro-greens is a "sensible" lunch, but what other establishment have you eaten at recently that has you walking out happy?
author: Sarah M.

description:
May not be as expansive or modern as the other locations, but for a quick Fi-Di lunch, this outpost of the popular local chain fills the bill. It's more quiet upstairs, but downstairs the food seems to arrive faster. Service is friendly and no-nonsense efficient like all of the other locations, and the food is on-par with the other downtown Henry's. 

If you don't have time to dine in, a nice thing they seem to do is turn just about every entree into an affordable rice plate. (Well not really a plate as much as a carton with half entree and half rice. It's more than enough food for one and pretty cheap--you just need your own plate. Round that off with a half-order of their scrumptuous dumplings (yes, they do half orders, yay!) and you've got a Hunan feast-for-one. 

Yum.
author: Aaron L.

description: Never have had a bad meal in this place. Kung Pao, the Tofu something and other, etc. Good lunch spot. No idea this place was in fact a chain
author: Jim B.

description:
Did not like at all! 
I went to Henry's for lunch with my coworkers. I ordered their Spicy Ham and mixed vegetables dish. First of all, it took a while for the food to come out, during my lunch schedule, every 5 minutes count... 
secondly, the ham had lots of fat on them, and i had to maneuver to get it out before i started eating it... and thirdly, it was way too salty. yes they do not use MSG, that's what they say and that's probably the only thing I liked about this place. it was not as good as other Chinese foods I have tasted and definitely not even an average place. 
it was not the best lunch experiences I have had. LOL to top it off, the fortune cookie that i had said " wear green next week" great. 
anyway, bad fortune cookie fortune aside, it really was not a restaurant worth walking over from SOMA.
author: Katelyn M.

description: The 2 stars are for the spice.  The onion pancake was thin & pretty good, but where's the onion?  The hot & sour soup was basically just salt; I've never had such bad hot & sour soup I have to say. I ordered the kung pao vegetable and have to say I am disappointed.  There was broccoli, bamboo shoot, onion, bell pepper & peanut, but no mushroom, though the taste is decent.  I wanted a lunch special, but there was nothing meatless to choose from.  So I had to order my entrée & rice separately which cost an additional $1.25 on top of the $8.75 dish & I wanted the soup, another $2.50 & onion cake, another $2 & that came out to be like $18 with taxes & tip.  Boy that was an expensive lunch.  But I have to say the portion was big & I had left overs to take home.
author: Sasa L.

description: We were the only ones there, which was kind of cool cause that makes me feel rich. But the food was bland and greasy, which didn't make me feel rich.
author: David S.

description:
Large portions for the financial district.  The food was alright, but it wasn't very spicy.  Even the hot chili paste on the table wasn't very hot.

Kung pao beef was good, the orange chicken had a very 'fresh orange peel' taste, dumplings were alright.

The Henry's Hunan on Church is much better.
author: Light Bulb J.

description: I always order the Hunan ham dish and it is usually very good. Sometimes they will ask you if you want your dish with steamed rice. If you say yes, you will get the dinner portion, which is more expensive than the lunch plate. Kind of sneaky if you ask me.
author: YM L.

description:
I used to eat at the Henry's at Dakota street with my dad all the time. The recipe's are standard across locations. The meat pie and the dumplings are two dishes you will NEVER regret getting. Their velvet chicken, kung pao chicken, broccoli beef, beef with green onions and just about everything are good. It's definitely a consistent good time, and it's cheap. Well sort of. For as good as it is anyways,

Two MUST HAVE dishes at this place:

1) Their dumplings. As far as I'm concerned they are the best in the city
2) Diane's Meat pie (Share with someone)

Sometimes I just get a half order of both of these and that's my lunch. The meat pie is very unique, so you won't find it elsewhere.
author: Chris G.

description: Great place for lunch when you are in the SF Financial District. I love their Kung Pao Shrimp.  Its a popular place, so go early to get a seat.
author: Ana C.

description: Expensive. 2 dishes at lunch came to $25 w tip. Food no better than Panda Express. Price really unreasonable for run of the mill Chinese.
author: Quince P.

description:
I wanted so much to like this place.  It's very close to our house.  The people who work there seemed very friendly, and the decor is tastefully done.  

Unfortunately, the food was THE WORST I can ever recall having in any Chinese restaurant!   We ordered the vegetarian version of the string beans as one dish, and we ordered the Country Vegetables and Tofu as the other dish  The green beans came out first, and upon eating the first bite, I said, "Wow, these beans are GREASY! Did somebody accidentally spill the bottle of oil in here?"  But then the tofu and country vegetables dish came out, and it was even worse!  No subtle flavors or sauce, only GREASE GREASE GREASE!  The tofu, vermicelli noodles, and vegetables (mostly cabbage, I guess), were all just one monochrome unsightly mess of beige bland greasiness.  

Also, no one ever asked us how we liked our food, and they took forever to bring us the check.  Eeesh.  My sweetheart and I felt sick the rest of the evening from this horrible food.  The other restaurants on Church St were packed for dinner (7 p.m. on Friday) and Henry's Hunan was almost empty when we came in.  I guess now I know why!
author: Rachel D.

description:
The sandwich board that sits outside the restaurant belies the quality of food hidden within it's walls. This is a very good restaurant at a price that is uncommon in the Financial District.

First and foremost, do not go to this restaurant without trying the dumplings. They are fantastic, and the signature dish of this establishment. The dumplings aren't fried like pot stickers, they're light and tasty.

You can't go wrong with any of their specials on the menu. It's funny that this little spot is within a couple blocks of the Financial heart of SF.  It seems, quite frankly, out of place in relation to the rest of the restaurants, but, like a diamond in the rough, this place is exquisite.

They have an upstairs room for entertaining large parties, and, as a friend has often told me, there is no place more disarming in the financial district, and I would recommend bringing your next Power lunch here.

In short, Henry's Hunan is a great restaurant in San Francisco's Financial district. If you need a quick bite, and you like Chinese food, this is the place to go.
author: Joshua G.

description: I've had many great Chinese cuisine experiences in San Francisco, but so far Henry's has ranked right up there with the very, very best of them.
author: Miguel S.

description: One of my favorite places to eat lunch in the Financial District.   Love the dumplings and the meat pie is sooooo good!!!!!!
author: QT P.

description: George likes his Kung Pao spicy.  And that's just how you get it here.  This gem is worth a trip to San Fran all on its own.  We make it a stop on every visit we have here and it never disappoints.  This last time around, we stopped in for lunch.  The place was packed and the service left something to be desired.  But, oh the food.  Not swimming in heavy sauce and good and spicy.
author: Dan G.

description:
3.5 Stars.

The no msg kitchen is offset by high sodium and grease, HOWEVER, the dishes turn out to be quite surprisingly decent....  It must be their WOK!  Super high heated wok yields great flavorful dishes!

The menu is just ordinary to me, broccoli chicken, broccoli beef, kung poa stuff, you know, the chinese-y dishes.

The velvet chicken dish is becoming my favorite.  The portion is freaking huge.  One order can feed me for 3 meals (if I am on a budget... which is always....)  Knowing that there's no msg is a plus, the high heated wok dish do make me crave for it from time to time.  But you just can't have it too often.  I'll be sodium OUT!
author: Gigi T.

description: The best Hunan cuisine I've found in these United States. Brandy Ho? Ha! They use hot sauce. Here, fresh peppers are in all the good stuff.  Yes, they have some mild dishes for those with delicate palates.  But I like it hot. My favorites are the Harvest Pork (forget everything you know about "Twice Cooked Pork"--this is different) and anything with smoked ham. I've never been to Hunan Province, but I suspect that if I went there, the food would be more like Henry's than anyone else's. Like Mama used to make. (Look in the kitchen: Mama is making it.)
author: Charlie G.

description: This place is so great. Ok it's old and shabby but the waitstaff is really attentive. The food and portions are amazing. The lunch specials are a great value. I love sitting at the bar and watching the ladies cook in the giant woks.
author: Vito G.

description:
Hunan Polish Sausage = PURE GENIUS.

That's the ultimate definition of fusion cuisine.  They may have other good things on the menu here, but I'll never know.  I can get chow mein anywhere, but where else can you get Hunan Polish Sausage?
author: Doctor L.

description:
This review is for lunch take out. I ordered the kun pao chicken and the combination fried rice. I am the dummy and ordered ala carte, instead of one of the lunch specials.  It was a lot to eat! 

I didn't stay to eat but got a look around - the place is not that big but the servers were busy and it looked pretty organized on getting food out.  

I was offered hot sauce and paper plates. The lady gave me 4 plates thinking I was sharing.  I took the plates and told her it's all for me!!! 

The kung pao chicken smelled delicious and is really good and spicy.  The fried rice was off the hook. That is now my favorite place to eat fried rice. Everyone in my office stopped by my desk to see what was smelling so good. 

I will be back and this time will eat in the restaurant! Yum is word here!
author: Lauren W.

description:
More of 3.5 stars.

This has the same consistent quality as the one in SOMA. Good and solid somewhat medium spicy food (comparing with Spices but I am not sure if it really is Hunan), perfect on a coldee day in SF. 

It has two floors and upstairs seems to be a bit less hectic.

Food wise, Velvet chicken was very good and with tender pieces, Mongolian beef was with good flavour, Kung Pao chicken with string beans and veggies was also hot and spicy. The rice was so so (the only mild complaint) as it's drier but then with the good sauce I did end up having 2 full plates of food! 

Service was good and fast except the last dish took a bit longer to come. Be sure to go there before 12:15pm or you will be waiting in line. 

And definitely a Peet's double shot Cap moment right afterwards to fight the starch coma!

And it's only $40 for 4 including tip!! Can't beat that!!
author: T L.

description:
This is a solid go-to for a quick work lunch. I get the dumplings (with a great spicy sauce that opens up my sinuses) and a side of rice -- all for $6 with tax. Not bad at all.

Unfortunate downside of being a white girl: they never give me chopsticks. :(
author: Catherine E.

description:
This is one of the best hole in the walls I have discovered. We were in and out in 20 minutes with hot and sour soup (complimentary) and tomato beef chow mein. 

Service was fast and friendly, and the food was filling and spicy deliciousness. Worth the visit if you are in the financial district.
author: Amy S.

description: Great no-frills, hole-in-da-wall FiDi lunch place for fast, flavorful, and yes, greasy Chinese food.  Lunchtime is crowded so if you can go before or after the rush all the better. I'm always down for the Henry's Special (yes, i'm a wimp.  medium spicy only), which comes with a healthy smattering of shrimp, scallops, chicken, cloud ears, bamboo shoots, carrots, bell peppers, and onions all over rice.  Dare you to try the Mabo Tofu & tell me it's not addicting, too.  I feel my arteries clogging up as we speak . . .
author: Peg S.

description:
Man, I just love this place.  I have been eating here for going on 6 years and it's nice to have people remember you.  The staff/owners are exceedingly nice and they are always quick, efficient, attentive and awesome while I sit at the countertop and read something boring like the Wall Street Journal. 

While sitting at the counter you can stare at all the workers preparing food and you can see for yourself that this is a clean establishment.  The woman in front of me is always patiently making by HAND dumplings which are so super tasty. That and those DAMN pork pies that make me weak in the knees.  

Mid week I usually get a chicken/broccoli or a beef/broccoli craving.  Broccoli is very good for you, so I use that excuse every time I power down a plate of this goodness.  Seriously, this is my favorite FiDi hang, be prepared to wait for a table at lunch tome, or sit by yourself at the counter, there really is never a wait. 

Five Big ASS Stars.
author: Claire C.

description:
I used to be a fan of Henry. Hell I would have taken a bullet for the guy.  But within the past 2 years Henry's Hunan has decided to "dumb down" their dishes. 

I'm sure Henry's old school recipes that he started his restaurant empire with are still great (I have his cookbook, they are). But when you go to his restaurant now, and ask for some Harvest Pork that'll light a fireworks display in your mouth, you're served a dish with barely enough fire to light a match.
 
Sure, now they might be reaching out for a new customer base that doesn't like starting a 4 alarm fire in their mouths, a more sane customer that probably tips better, and is classier. But Hunan food is about the SPICE. YOUR LOGO IS A DAMN SMILING PEPPER! 

"Hunan people can live without meat, but they can't live without hot peppers" - Henry W.S. Chung 

Don't make me bring Sriracha (Cock Sauce) next time I decide to give into Nostagia.
author: Alex M.

description: This place is pretty solid.  The food is on the greasy side, but definitely tasty and extremely affordable!  Customer service here is also excellent.  Bonus points for having a receptionist and phone person who speaks english.  Another bonus for letting you pay with credit card without a minimum.  4 stars as a general review, but 4.5 stars when compared to other places in the area.
author: Dean L.

description:
I came in Tuesday and ordered one of the Tuesday rice plate lunch specials that cost $6.75.  The manager asked if I wanted my rice on the side and I told him that it didn't matter...

The food came with the rice on the side.  I hungrily ate most of everything, although I felt the pork way too salty...

When it came time to pay, the tab was $12!  Huh?  The manager claimed that since the rice was served on the side that the meal was ordered a la carte...

I ended up paying $9 for the meal ($6.75 plus tax and tip), but feel that I shouldn't have had to argue for that.  This seems like a ruse to rip unsuspecting people off.  I would think that a SF "institution" like Henry's with multiple locations wouldn't have to sink to this level to make an extra buck...
author: Nathan W.

description:
