Whenever I dine out here with my coworkers, I have to order either Diana's Meat Pie or the Noodle with Meat Sauce dish--two examples of their "non-spicy" dishes.  Among our favorites are also Chicken with String Beans and Velvet Chicken.  

Henry's service may be perceived as bad, but I like their no-nonsense policy, especially when I just want to get in, grub, and get out.  Sometimes, I really Heart Zero-Frills.
author: Lily T.

description:
It is not Hunan Chinese food.
It is not American Chinese food.
It is not real Chinese food.

It is just AWFUL Chinese food - so salty and greasy!
author: C L.

description:
I reviewed the Sansome St place a few weeks ago, and was on the search for some other Chinese food on the periphery of Chinatown. Saw this, but didn't put two and two together until I saw the meat pie on the menu.

This time, I ordered takeout, the pork chow mein noodles for $8. They brought it out, and it was in this little takeout box, I thought I got screwed. But, it was packed with spicy noodles and a decent amount of pork.

Food was good, like other reviewers before me, its a little pricey for what you are getting. Restaurant seemed a little grotty, but that's kinda normal in these parts.
author: Joseph T.

description: Stopped by here for lunch sat at the bar nice view of the good cooking. It is so intricate about how they cook their vegetables first you see broccoli American style and all of a sudden it turns Chinese. Had the Marty Special it was the most tastiest thing I have ever tasted in the whole wide world literally. For a good lunch come here it is so wonderful you will just want more til you die
author: Aurelio L.

description:
Dreadful food.  Some of the worst slop I've eaten.  Had Kung Pao Chicken.  Crappy service too, as the waitress hovered over us pushing us to order.  It took me a while to figure out what I wanted as the menu was not varied at all.

It takes A LOT for me to trash a place but it was truly awful.  Thankfully a friend paid for lunch that day.
author: Sparkely K.

description:
I rarely if ever eat in here, because they deliver. But I have on occasion, and if you do, you should try to sit upstairs. Because the downstairs is awkward and annoying, and the upstairs has better fenestration.

Anyway, it's our rainy day office lunch staple, and like I said, they deliver. All the dishes taste pretty much the same, but I happen to like the taste of the one sauce they apparently make every dish with. Also, I like spicy food. Their dishes are generous with the shrimp and chicken, and comforting in their way.

If any of you are wimps, ask for "medium spicy," or you could quit whining, you nancy.
author: Megan W.

description: Great place to go for lunch in the FiDi! Decent space for seating including an upstairs dining area. The food is good and you can make it really spicy if that's your thing! They always have a ~$7 daily special and you can order it for pick-up and it's usually ready when you arrive; no matter how close you work.
author: Nii M.

description:
My office usually orders Christmas lunch from Henry's, and we have our party in a conference room with a bunch of cardboard boxes and plastic forks.  It's authentic, if nothing else. 

It's probably not fair for me to give this place a 3, but it's too spicy for my delicate (wimpy) palate to handle.   And the few times I've dined in, the wait was a disaster.  We usually call up a big order for our office (whether or not it's Christmas), and send a couple of people to pick it up.  Now that I've learned that trick, I probably won't bother to deal with their lousy lunchtime seating.
author: Sharon M.

description: Come here often for lunch with my co-workers as it's only a few blocks a way from my work.  The place is extremely busy by noon so make sure to arrive way before noon.  We usually get here around 11:30.  Their dumplings are always good to start with (6 pieces).  You can order half as well.  Their spicy dishes are usually great.  My favorite is Henry's Special and Mongolian Beef.  Their non-spicy stuff is just average or below average.  Level of service is just average for an asian joint.
author: James C.

description:
A great lunch spot with some addicting dishes that have me returning fairly often.

Come early, especially if there are more than 2 of you.  There's typically a line out the door by 12:05 during the week.  Don't let the line intimidate you - you never have to wait more than 10 minutes or so, usually closer to 5.  Sit upstairs if you can, it's a little more relaxed.

After spending the last few years trying other dishes there, I keep going back to the same impressive ones.   

As an appetizer, the "Meat Pie" is awesome.  It's a fried onion cake with what I believe is ground beef and pork  in a spicy sauce, topped with shredded lettuce, topped again with another fried onion cake.  While very different in taste, it could best be described as like a tostada.  If having as an appetizer, order one for every four people.  It can be a bit heavy as a starter if you wind up having two wedges of that (1/2 the "pie").

The single best entree they have originally sounded (to me) as the least appetizing (yes, even less appetizing than meat pie).  The Smoked Ham with String Beans is pretty incredible.   The smoked ham itself is more or less a kind of bacon.  It's smokiness bleeds into the balckbean sauce that lightly covers the entire dish.  These are probably some of the most satisfying green beans I've ever had.

I'm also a fan of their Hunan Shrimp.  It's not amazing, but it's very good.  The sauce, whatever it is, complete it.  Bamboo shoots are cooked enough to avoid the stringiness.  The onions are rich in texture and work very well with the spicy sauce.  The carrots and bell, frankly, are forgettable.

They don't get the full five stars because they could improve upon their consistency.   For example, some days the green bean/ham dish isn't amazing, but just good.  Also, service is more miss than hit.  Finally, it's a damn madhouse in their.  They should really let you pay your bill through your server, but you have to go to the tiny counter with all the other people waiting to pay and waiting to be seated.
author: Dave H.

description:
Helyahmhan,
I remenber this joint from back in the day. The first chinese joint to sport the big "No MSG" sign. Hecka good chinese food. I remember one night we couldn't figure out what the chinese waiter was asking us... do loo want a light bulb... Do we want a fuckin light bulb of course not? ohhh light bulb! yes we'd a like rice bowl with our good ass asiatic grub. The same night we'd gotten a flat out in back of the restaurant and the whole kitchen crew (I felt like I was in the chinese indy 5oo) changed our tire for us. Made me wanna be a cook. those guys were heroes. I was like ten it was my birthday, I think? Memories man what a great place.
author: Rhasaan F.

description: So disappointed.  After reading all the great reviews, I was looking forward to experiencing the same cuisine that I used to enjoy years ago at the Vallejo Street Henry's.  I didn't expect any ambience but the food was salty and the service was SLOW.
author: Dorothy W.

description: For $16 for kung pao beef, rice, and hot and sour soup I would have expected better.  The rice was overcooked and mushy.  The beef was tough.  I've been to this place a number of times.  If you are going to charge a premium, make sure the product is great.  I prefer Brandy Ho's.
author: Joseph M.

description:
Here's my take on Henrys. You need to realize that not all locations are the same. While the menu may look the same or similar, the way they prepare the dishes varies by location. 

In my opinion the Sacramento Street location is BY FAR the best one that I have tried and the Battery Steet location is the worst. The SoMa one is my second favorite location.

This review is based on the Sacramento Street location since that is the one I frequent. 

First off - Meat Pie is a must order. Now, I know that some of you out there are saying to yourself "Meat Pie sounds gross - I'll pass"  

Big Mistake....it's addicting and delicious - try it and you will like it.

Other dishes that are good: Kung Pao anything, Shrimp with meat sauce, Henrys Special (Chicken, Prawns, Scallop), Hot and Sour anything, Chicken with Black Bean Sauce, Beef with String Bean

The deal with Henry's is that all of the dishes are infused with a smoky chili flavor that is not commonly found in most chinese restaurants. It's unusual and delicious. 

Some days the dishes are hotter than others, it's not exactly health food either, and you better buy some POWERFUL gum or breath mints if you plan to take Muni home from work after eating Hunie as I call it.

My wife can tell 6 hours later that I had Kung Pao from Hunie and she won't kiss me either....but it's still worth it!

5 stars since it's my fav chinese spot in the city but it ranges from 3-5 stars on a given day. If you are not thrilled the first time, try again because when they are on it's sublime.

Busy on weekdays for lunch, large take out contingent as well. Make sure you call ahead if you plan to pick up
author: Joel V.

description:
MY FAVORITE CHINESE FOOD ON THE PLANET!
I grew up in SF and have since moved to LA for work, but EVERY time I visit the Bay Area I make sure to get take-out from Henry's Hunan!
All the food is amazing, but DO NOT MISS THE SPECIALS!
Henry's Special is my personal favorite (spicy) and everyone loves Diana's special meat pie. The actual restaurant is quaint, though not too impressive. However, the take out window is very convenient and there is parking out front for take-out orders.
author: Greg B.

description: I've been going to Henry's on Natoma for about 10 years.  It is by far my favorite Chinese restaurant in the City!  You have to try the Kung Pao chicken (ask for white meat, which is a dollar more, but worth it).  I also order it spicy.  If you like spice you will absolutely love this dish and Henry's Hunan!  If you haven't experienced spicy, Henry's will help you ease into it, and after awhile, you'll crave the hot!  Also some of my other favorite dishes are the hot sauteed string beans as well as the mu shu vegetable and also the Henry's Special!  But I have to say that all the dishes there are good!  Enjoy!
author: Paris S.

description:
Really high-quality, authentic Chinese food with the exception that it is not as spicy as Hunanese food. So if, like me, you want it extra hot you need to order it extra hot.

The Harvest Pork ($8.00) was excellent and really tasty. The Eight Delight Vegetables ($7.50) was just literally just vegetables, oil, and spices, which is the authentic style, but it lacks flavor. 

Diana's Meat Pie Special ($6.95) is practically a must order appetizer. 

The Polish Sausage ($8.75) dish is a personal favorite, and the pork dishes are really what they specialize in.

They have an open kitchen in the back where you can sit at a counter and watch them cook your food.
author: Adam Z.

description:
No fancy decor here but daumm the food is great!  I'm so glad they have multipule locations so I can get my Henry's fix in several neighborhoods.

I know I can't prove it, but I believe there may be adictive ingredients in Diana's Meat Pie and the Henry's Special.  Both unique to Henry's and both so yummy that I keep ordering the same thing when I go.  But also other dishes are good too, dumplings, string beans, even the polish sausage hunan style.

Skip House of Nanking and just try Henry's once, you'll be hooked.
author: Aj D.

description:
It looks like a hole in the wall kinda place, but that's what makes it so good! Yummy, yummy food. I love going here when I'm cold. The people are so nice too, they greet almost everyone by name.

Here's my favorite:
-Hot&Sour Chicken - get this over rice. yummy
-Spicy Shrimp w/ Bean Curd Sauce
-Diane's Special Meat Pie
-the first chow mein on the menu

If you like spicy, you'll like it here.
author: Ang L.

description: I ordered the combo fried rice and it's very good, taste and size of portion.Well worth the price. I will come more often to try other. They do have a special for each day but you need to ask for it , in which the dishes are $7.
author: Ying X.

description:
I have been to Henry's a few times now and I must say I really like their food.  The Kung-pao chicken is to die for and I have been really happy w/everything that I've ordered. The staff are all really nice and you really get a sense that they are firmly planted in the community. 

Good place, only complaint is that it closes at 5!
author: Jenna K.

description: Henry's Hunan is once of my regular lunch rotations in FIDI.  I absolutely love the dish - Howard's Special made extra hot (kung pao pork).  It's enough for two meals.  Nothing fancy but great, honest food.  Very nice friendly people too!
author: Melissa A.

description:
Excellent food with just the right heat to jumpstart one's system, especially on a cold San Francisco day. Their dry-sauteed string beans with meat sauce, hunan fish, beef and broccoli, chicken chow mein and hot and sour soup are great defaults.

The key in enjoying your meal is to make a reservation prior to 11:45am. Otherwise, the lunch crowd gets in and your food will get delayed, especially if you are with a group.
author: Miles G.

description:
Henry's "Will Induce Heartburn and Indigestion" Hunan Restaurant, in the FiDi/Chinatown area, is a popular spot, especially if you are doing the SOLO lunch. There is a ton of seating here for groups. Can choose between a downstairs or upstairs seat. The wait staff at the door might TACKLE you if you do not heed their warning, "There is no room upstairs!". 

Avoid the lunch rush if you need some nice table space. Otherwise my favorite thing about this place, food ASIDE, is sitting at the counter. Only counters I have sat at to eat are a pub, think we call that a BAR, and a breakfast diner. Makes the meal so much more intersting. Can watch the chefs WHIP out the lunches in their giant woks, flipping the oil soaked ingredients with the biggest kitchen UTENSILS this side of something.

Place is a bit pricer than H K nearby, and quality is not half as good. It will suffice. Just be prepared to be clutching your heart, chest and any other vital organs as you walk back. Place is spicy!
author: Ryan G.

description:
This place is The Bomb! Great for lunch in the Financial District.  If you go during lunch you better get their early or you'll have to wait. The price is right, the service is fast, and the food is delicious.  I have not had one bad thing here yet.  It you do not like oily food, it's probably not for you.  But for the style of Chinese food it doesn't get much better than Henry's.

Make sure you get the Meat Pie...
author: Peter W.

description:
WOW, this place loves to pour on the salt. 

I went here for lunch with a coworker and we ordered the lunch specials for Tuesday (Kung P Chik, Marty's dish (i order this based on the reviews), and a half order of the "meat pie" (not on the lunch menu). The "meat pie" was delicious but everything else was horrible. The Marty's dish was ham and chicken, all i could taste was HAM and Salt; which equals dehydration. The KPC had potential but damn it too was SALTY. 

Corns recommendation: The Meat Pie (which looks like a tostada), steamed rice, and a ice cold coke. Stay away from the lunch menu, there is a reason its printed on paper.
author: andres c.

description: The food is incredible and the staff couldn't be any nicer. Try the Henry's Special, Kung Pao Chicken, or chicken and green beans. Oh yeah, the pot stickers are best in the city.
author: John B.

description:
Eddie and Jeff are great people.  We love them so much we almost feel guilty going to other chinese restaurants!

Food is great too!

AND its BYOB!
author: Jeff G.

description: I love this place.  Meat Pie, baby.
author: Adam B.

description: I was here on Friday, Octorber 15, 2010.  I waited freaking 30 mins for my food and when asked the guy he seemed like he forgot my order...so i left.  it's going to take a while for me to come back to this place.
author: Erick L.

description:
Okay, so as of now this is my ULTIMATE FAVORITE SPOT!!! 

In the FIDI area there are so many choices but after awhile you realize everything is the really the same, that is until you come here. I came with my boss, sat right at the counter where you can watch them prepare you amazing food. I got the Sweet and Spicy fish, which was worth 5 stars...and my boss got some Tofu dish, which was AMAZING, since I don't really eat Tofu and I had two helpings of that. All in all this is an AMAZING, GOOD, SLIGHTLY SPICY, LUNCH SPOT!!! 
I try to make it here once a week, but my schedule doesn't always let me..but if I could I would definitely be here weekly. 
Also I agree with the other reviewers, the cashier chick is very nice as well!!
author: Ashlei T.

description:
2nd time to eat here and 2 time disappointed.

All I can say is they are VERY generous with the oil.
Ordered Kung pao chicken.... wasn't spicy and pretty oily. An hour later I was in the commode.
Just finished trying to eat their meat pie which looks good in pictures. The pie topping is nice. Soft though expected it to be crunchy.
The inside is gross. Minced Pork filling which seems to have been soaked in oil. I guess that is why the topping is soft ..... too wet/oily filling.
Phone order was ready for pickup after 30mins. By then food was cold.
 Never again!
author: Shiru M.

description: Cheap and friggin yummy. I was out here a few years ago for a TDY, and I think we ate here 3x per week during lunch. I don't know what the hell I ate, as our resident Taiwanese friend did all of the ordering, but I was awesome times fantastic to the neato power. I miss the food. I miss it a lot.
author: Sarah C.

description:
Cheap and good chinese food in the Financial District? 

Come and dine in the bar counter and be ready to feast on some delicious hunan style cooking.  My favorite dishes are the ham and green beans, scallion cake and dumplings.  When you sit at the counter you can watch the chefs prepare and cook the meals in a jiffy.  The ham is an awesome pairing with the green beans.  They marinate and roast the ham themselves and it's to die for.

It's a family owned chain and they have a few throughout the city.  Can't wait to try their other items.
author: Cathy L.

description: Henry's special is great. Shrimp, good scallops, and spicy. Also, you can't go wrong with the meat pie.
author: CJ B.

description:
It's seriously a gut warmer. If I need to be woken up internally mid day, then Henry's is the place to go. My coworkers and I love this spot. It's always crowded (a good sign!) and they do not skimp out on the spice. 

It's very reasonably priced with great portions. They may rush you out during peak lunch hours, but they also serve you rather quickly. I've also ordered at the counter for takeout, and if you're willing to get smooshed behind the door bc of the horde of folks wanting their Hunan, then it's also a decent deal.

The veggies are crisp and fresh, no mystery looking meat and super casual. Not for timid bellies though.

Update 5/22
I just had an office lunch with 13 people. We all stuffed ourselves silly for a little over $130. My new favorite is the shrimp napa cabbage dish. SO GOOD!!
author: Jessica P.

description: An excellent place to stop for lunch, especially if you enjoy hot, hearty meals.  I always leave this place full of food.  Great!
author: Thomas H S.

description:
I love this place. It's super crowded every time i go there for a reason. I have never had such awesome potstickers in my life, and I know they make them from scratch because I've seen them making them, not like some restaurants that fry ling lings and serve them on a platter for $5. The meat pie is also delish! Drink lots of water, though, cuz it can get salty, and head for the gym afterwards because you'll eat a lot. 

Oh, and props to the woman who heads the place, she is SUPER friendly and I heard that she saves up food from leftover entrees and take outs that people don't pick up and saves them for homeless people who know her place and come by for the food every day.
author: L K.

description:
Dang, I love the food at this place. But I only order 2 things. 

1. Chicken and stringbeans over rice. I could have this every day and never want anything else.

2. Meat pie. mmmmmmmm.

The other stuff, I dunno and I don't give a shit.
author: Jessica O.

description: I've talked to people who purport near death experiences and they all say the same thing.  I saw this white light and when I went through it, I entered Henry's Hunan on the other side.  That sums up my sentiments.  You can not go wrong with any dish....PERIOD.  The hotter the better.  And the cozy, bustling ambiance at the Sacramento St. location is all part of Henry's mystique.  I can't wait to die and go to Henry's in heaven.  One two three four five six seven...all the way to Henry's in Heaven.
author: Rick W.

description: I LOVE the fried rice! Off the hook like no other!
author: KRC K.

description:
We call this place "Henry's House Horrors" based on some of the things we have seen over the years, yet it still stays in rotation, we go there at least once a week, every week for, oh, 8 or so years now?

I get the curry chicken, hot.  I leave with a nice sheen of sweat.  Good stuff, big quantities.

If you go at noon, good luck getting a seat, and if you have more than about 4 people you might be sat upstairs at the "big" round table, which sits about 10 or so people, and you will be mixed in with a bunch of strangers.  You would think this would add to a jovial lunch atmosphere but it seems that everyone just sits at the big table quiet and awkward.

Eat at the "bar" in the back where you can watch the food being made, it's pretty amazing.

The general cleanliness of the place is pretty scary.  The kitchen area looks fine-ish but the floors are pretty messy.  For the love of god, don't ever look inside that dumb-waiter that they use to shuttle food upstairs.  I did once and nearly needed therapy to get me past the mess I saw.

Cheap, big quantities, pretty good overall food.  Good lunch place if you can make it by 11:45am.
author: Doug M.

description:
I just ate an early lunch at Henry's, and now I'm sitting back in my office chair and feel a little out of context.  After feasting as I just did, I feel like it should be the weekend, or time to go out to a bar or show; not back in front of the computer in the middle of the day, middle of the week, staring at a desk full of papers.  I guess what I'm getting at is this lunch was too good for a Tuesday 11 AM meal.

The food here packs a punch.  I recommend Henry's shreaded pork, which comes with a mix of spinach and scrambled eggs and a nice combination of spices.  If your taste buds are craving flavor, this dish will not disappoint, and all for under $9.

The building itself is not the cleanest, fanciest establishment.  But after you start eating, the background will just be...background.

Hook up the pork, Henry!
author: Joe C.

description: Great food at Sacramento street store but they BS you on the wait times for to go service. Was told 20 minutes, went in at 25 and wasn't even in the order queue!
author: Dan S.

description: I come here for lunch a bunch. Come early, as it can get crowded. If you are getting take out, call ahead. That said, get the shrimp,  the meat pie appetizer, but avoid the ham and green bean dish. It is way way too salty. One dish and the meat pie appetizer will take care of a normal eater for lunch, the next dinner, and a late night snack.
author: Ushra M.

description:
I'm always weary of Chinese restaurants that don't have a menu in Chinese.  They usually serve unauthentic and uninspired "American Chinese food" like Orange Chicken (nasty) and General Tsao's Chicken (double nasty).  So when I walked in to this restaurant located in a dark little alleyway and sat down next to tables of (no offense) white folks without a single Chinese customer in sight and given an all-English menu, I  was already very very weary of this place.  

But much to my surprise, the food is actually pretty good!  Granted it is not 100% authentic Hunan food, I mean where are you going to find that in the Bay area anyway?  You're better off going to NYC or LA, or better yet, China for truly authentic dishes.  But that aside, the flavors are surprisingly good and strong.  I ordered a curry beef with green peppers dish and it was a huuuge portion with a mountain fo sliced beef in this kind of satay curry sauce.  Another spinach, egg, fungus, and pork dish was very good as well.  It was simple but very comforting, not at all like a dish you would serve at a restaurant, but rather reminds me of a home cooked dish my mom used to make.  Maybe because I had very low expectations coming in, but the tasty food was definitely a pleasant surprise.  

The prices are reasonable and on par with other Chinese restaurants around the area.  Portions are huge!  I suggest coming here with a large group and order tons of dishes to share family style.  That is, after all, the way Chinese food should be eaten :)
author: Nancy J.

description:
Spicy Chinese food.

I've been here three times during the lunch hour rush and all three times there were tables available. 
The to-go service is also very fast- order and ready to go within 5 minutes every time. My office is a good 10minutes away, but it's still piping hot by the time I get back to my desk. THAT, my friends, is impressive.

Recommendations:

*String beans with chicken* (also comes with beef or shrimp): beans are fresh and crunchy and the white meat chicken is moist and tender.

*Steamed dumplings* : a great appetizer-- served with a delicious spicy dipping sauce.

*Kungpao chicken (or beef)*: you can order it as an entree or over rice ($6.80 out the door). 

The portions are big too so I usually have enough left over for mid-afternoon munchies.
author: Lily L.

description:
I would give 3.5 stars, but I can't.

Generally packed at lunch time from the financial district crowd. But don't let this diminish the fact that the food is solid, prices reasonable, and the flavor will satisfy your hunger (so long as you don't burn out your taste buds). 

I recommend the black bean chicken over a bed of white rice. Certainly one of the more mild dishes, and it may leave you with a case of food coma - but only because it's so good! Go spicy or go mild, but try some of their onion cakes if your waistline can handle it. 

The food is a bit greasy, service a bit spotty...but the true measure of this place is the food. And it's on target for sure!
author: Aaron F.

description: My favorite thing about Henry's is how it makes all of my coworkers wander by my desk drooling over the delicious aroma of my lunch. It actually smells like meat, veggies and seasoning rather than just grease. Probably the best chinese in SF and definitely the best in the Financial District. Be careful though, when they say spicy they mean it!!!
author: Kandace K.

description:
Now Henry's is authentic Chinese food. I heard this place has been around since the 70's and during the lunch rush, it is always packed with people dining in as well as getting to-go orders.
I usually get the string beans with chicken (my old boss got me into it). It has this spicy chili sauce that they probably stir fry the chicken and string beans in. I haven't tried anything else but I bet it's all good if the one dish I did try I really, really, really liked.
Usually my entree (you will have to order rice separately) costs a little over $10 but so worth it. It tastes fresh, full of flavor and not Americanized at all. And I bring the leftovers home with me. YUUUUUM!
author: Britney C.

description: I've been going here at least twice a month with an old colleague for at least 4 years. The food is always fresh, extremely consistent, and delicious. I like the place because they don't really use garlic - that is key for a financial district lunch-time spot! I always order the shrimp and spicy tofu (#11), and onion pancake. The portions are huge (I always take home about half of my dish) and it's cheap. Be sure to get in the door before the 12pm rush! Final note: if you want it spicy, you have to tell them "extra spicy."
author: Chihee K.

description:
This place got rave reviews from a friend of mine who works in FiDi. So I decided to come try it with him during weekday, lunch hour.  We arrived at 11:45am to try to avoid the lunch crowd.  We were able to get a table quickly upstairs, and ordered immediately.  We ordered the Vegetarian Kung Pao and Garlic Chicken dishes.  The food took a LONG time to arrive.  We left the restaurant at 1:15pm with most of our food in take-out containers.

The taste of the food was ok...just ok.  It could be very spicy (for those who can't handle that - ask them to tone it down).
author: Mon L.

description:
CoWorkers and I used to frequent this place quite a bit when I worked in the city. I attribute at least a 10lb weight gain to Henry's Special, a combination seafood/meat dish that is hands down, the best chinese food I have ever had. 
The restaurant itself is a dive, service isn't great, and they pack you in and rush you out. But no one goes here for the ambience, it's all about the best Hunan and that is it.  
They guys would go crazy over the meat pie dish as well, even had a birthday for a friend catered by Henry's Meat Pies. Once you look at the meat a little further, you may never eat it again. Fair warning, it is a mysterious dish to say the least.
Either way everyone needs to eat here at least once!
author: Christine S.

description:
I'd give more stars for the fact that they make and serve a decent-enough green onion pancake that I haven't been able to find since Satay House in Berkeley shut down years and years ago without any hope to ever return.  Dammit.  They had the best green onion pancake ever.  Henry's is more thin and crispy, not the perfectly chewy-but-crispy, thicker type that Satay House had.  Henry's cake is kind of expensive, about $4 for one cake cut into 4 pieces, whereas Satay House gave at least 3 thick cakes worth for about the same price.  

Food-wise, back when I ate meat, it was all about the Marty's Special, but *only* if we were dining in rather than taking out.  For some reason the takeout version is lackluster, but when we dine in, the smoked ham isn't overwhelming with salt, and the veggies are perfectly tender and flavorful.  It comes piping hot, which is how I like all of my hot food.  The dumplings are actually a satisfying, hearty appetizer that didn't leave me wondering if I'd be sated enough with just my entree.  The fried rice is just OK; no real flavor to mention unless it's the smoked ham.

I'm a fan of the dry-sauteed string beans, though.  Those are just the right amount of spicy and not teeming with sodium.  Not soggy, just crispy enough but not raw, either.

Would give another star if the dishes were more consistent when ordering takeout, compared to how good it is when I dine in.  It's so weird that packing it up to go makes such a huge difference in taste...
author: Joss H.

description: I don't even think this is an affiliate of the other Henry's Hunan.  I called an order for something on the menu that I found online and they said they didn't have that item.  So I ordered a hunan chicken lunch special and when I got there, they said they don't make hunan chicken, but they had a kung pao chicken that was my order. Okay, I guess.  Weird because you're restaurant is called "Henry's Hunan".  I checked outside that maybe I went to the wrong restaurant, but no.  And then it wasn't that good; therefore the one star for "never again".
author: Marcus M.

description: Eh...everyone in my office loves this place but I've been really unimpressed with it.  All their dishes are waaay too greasy, even when I order it with light oil...Just does not even come close to 77 Chinese food in my opinion....
author: wingless g.

description: i love this place, i have to hit it up every time I am in Chinatown. I always get the meat pie, the only reason I am knocking down a star is because they are so greasy and i honestly don't know what meat they are made with..but they are awesome!! Its about a 3 block walk from the financial district but it is worth it!!
author: Annie S.

description: I just love this place. The food is so spicy and tasty I can't even count the number of times I've eaten here. It's at least a hundred over the past 15 years or so. I always get the Kung pao chicken because it's so good.  The meat pie is also a favorite. The prices are really low and they rarely ever raise them.  Maybe $.25 from 10 years ago.
author: Greg W.

description:
If you're in the mood for spicy, this is it.  Food is delicious, some of the best Hunan I've had in a while. The flavors dont run in from one dish to another, so you dont have to worry about everything tasting the same. I cant stand it when Chinese restaturants dishes all taste like theyre all using the exact same ingrediants. Casual cafe style restaurant. Plates average $10. Take a look at their menu 

http://henryshunanrestaurant.com/gallery.nxg

This place is packed during lunch... so come early. Great place for a quick bite to eat. Not the greatest place for large groups, although we have seated a group of 8-9 before. 

Ask for extra hot and you'll be sweating during your meal. Seating is limited, although they do have an upstairs seating arrangment. Great place for lunch.
author: Jay P.

description:
This restaurant is a favorite among my co-workers.
On most Mondays we end up going there as the place is less crowded than on other week days. I have tried the following vegetarian items and they all were very tasty:
Eight delight vegetables
Country Style vegetables
Hot and sour vegetables
They make the dishes very spicy, and also quite oily, but the taste is good enough to make you think  "calories be damned, I just want to enjoy my food". 
The waiters are polite and courteous and considering how crowded this place gets, I must say they do a pretty decent job of serving the customers.
author: kumar k.

description:
Kind of a paradox in terms of Hunan food.
Some very unique and nice dishes.

I have eaten on and off  here for over 20 years.

It has been much better in the past (hotter and spicier)

Marty's Special and the Diana's meat pie are unique and credible.

My main issue is that they don't make things hot and spicy anymore ,just salty.

Waaaaaaaaaaaaay too salty.

This is a so so rec.

Check it out if your in the neighborhood.
author: P G.

description:
Ok.  So maybe it wasn't exactly atmospheric.  Maybe we had to go up two flights of stairs and we were a little scared.  It was totally worth it!  That was the best hot & sour soup I've had in San Francisco.  It was in fact so tasty that I will be ordering it again - ASAP.

The whole meal was just delicious, and I'm a convert.
author: Wendy W.

description: If you like spicy food, try Harvest Pork. It is the best on the menu.
author: John S.

description: This is a treasure for me: a Henry's Hunan so close to my work I could stumble out from my work and be eating their yummy food.  This is a hole-in-the-wall joint.  There is a "bar" where you can take a stool and watch them cooking your food (and others' food) and wonder what their cooking.  Food is good, service is good, prices are excellent, and the food is quick - perfect for a lunch near work.
author: Greg R.

description: I am giving 5 stars for take out only.  The ambiance is about 1 star, great for quick business lunch with collegues terrible for a safe lunch date. Linda has been taking care of me for years and is very friendly.
author: micah g.

description:
Another Henry's Hunan location brought to us by Henry himself.

This place tastes just as good as the Natoma location, but has more of a Chinatown ambiance.  See my review of the Natoma location between 2nd and New Montgomery.  

Greasy, Tasty, Salty, Spicy, Yummy.

Sit at the kitchen counter to watch how Eliza's Meat Pie is truly made.  It will make you love it more.  The Dragon is back there putting his special sauce all over everything, and if you can see him, it is good luck.
author: Nate B.

description:
Great pork noodles with special spicy sauce. The meat pie is also very delicious.  

Seating is 2 levels.

The only complaint I have is when they took 30 minutes to cook the mao pao tofu dish.  It's pretty much the easiest dish on the menu. Grrrr...

Pay the bill downstairs and get a mint on the way out from all the garlic and hot sauce.
author: Jenny W.

description:
I love this place.  They are always friendly.  Linda has been there for years and is always helpful.

The meat pie and pot stickers are a must.  My other staple is the Harvest Pork.....mmmm, good.
author: Justin H.

description: I only can comment on the meat pie and the service.  Both were exceptional.  Unless your a competitive eater, you will be full when you leave.  I toted the spicy masterpiece to the hotel and ate it for both a early and late dinner.  It is so good I consider it worth the walk from Union Square, which is saying alot considering the spot is on Sacramento.
author: chris s.

description: SOMA location near Adolph Gaser's. Really great Hunan food although a little oil would be appreciated. The waitress forgot one dish which was lucky as the portions were very large. Chung Pao chicken, dry fried string beans with black beans and an order of dumplings. We asked for mild hot and the dishes were just enough to develop a low grade sweat. All dishes were very very good.
author: Marty T.

description:
Really delicious and spicy Hunan food.  We love the hot and sour chicken and Marty's special.  Onion cakes are to die for; chicken salad is also very good.  Always get a bottle or two of the hot oil to bring home.  It tastes great on anything you cook at home.  Yes, the food is oily and hot but that's what Hunan food is.  If you want light and non-spicy, go eat Weight Watcher's frozen food.  

The atmosphere is a little cold--big warehouse.  That's the only reason I give it 4 out 5 stars.  But, come for the food, not the ambience.  Betty at the front desk is always very friendly.  We've been eating at Henry's Hunan since it was a small place on Kearney Street (before the earthquake).
author: Ann F.

description: I love Henry's, I mainly go to the one located on Natoma that is more full service than this one. Weird but this Henry's doesn't have fried rice and even weirder how they have an upstairs area that gives me the creeps. But all that aside you can't beat the hot dishes they are known to serve. Kung Pao anything is superb (shrimp is my personal fav), spicy as all heck and so very good. I also like the Curry Beef and the green beans. This location is pretty much as the others, you must get there early if you expect to be seated quickly. And if you're taking it to go make sure to order over the phone so you don't have to wait.
author: La C.

description: This is one of my favorite restaurants in downtown.  My favorite dish is String Beans with Prawns.  The shrimp is tender and the green beans are fresh.  You can usually share with another and still have some left-over to take with you.  The chow mein is also worth a try.
author: Denny L.

description:
I just love this place. Food quality is great, and servers are friendly and fast. One of the cool things is sitting at the counter watching the chiefs cook. Try the specials!

Love the bean curd with meat sauce, but I don't care for the "special meat pie" but that's just me.

Only open til 5PM, so it's for lunch, not dinner, and some people (not me) report spotty service.
author: Bob D.

description: wonderful spot. Sat at the counter.  The ladies who make the food are all business and very efficient....oh, yeah, and the food is great.  Tried the hacked chicken and the kung pao.  Very good.
author: Tom P.

description: OK place and prices are good. It pretty hard to get seating during 11pm-12:30pm during the week. Best to call in and get food to go but it sometimes takes a while 20-25 minutes.
author: Kim D.

description:
This place made me feel guilty... I thought I was above stiffing on a tip until I walked out of this place today. I mean, I've been a waiter before, so I know how important tips are; I ALWAYS leave at least something, even at those place where you don't really have to, like Starbucks (not that I go there). But now that we're beyond that, it should be clear that I'm not a cheapskate or harsh critic. No, it wasn't even that the service was bad, albeit that it took a long time for me to get my food and they didn't really do a whole lot for me beside bring it... But I have to say the staff here was really friendly. I felt terrible about not leaving a tip... But it was the food that did it. The food was ABSOLUTELY awful. I mean, I guess it was my fault, because for some reason it had slipped my mind in there that Hunan food puts an emphasis on spicy, and it probably pissed off the cook that I ordered the Orange Sauce Chicken. Well, this chicken must have been made from one of those rubber toy chickens... The consistency of the "meat" was very gummy; I deduced that this was due to the meat being more breading than actual meat, but it was obvious that it couldn't have been cooked properly. I hated it. And as I sat there chewing on this unsavory cuisine, surrounded by obnoxious corporate shills, I could feel myself wondering what the hell made this overcrowded place so popular. But it wasn't until I saw the check that I couldn't bring myself to spent one more cent here; $10.30 for a shitty lunch that consisted of water, steamed rice, and hardly edible chicken.

I left there feeling so pissed off that I had just blown $10 on terribly shitty food, and would have given them only 1 star, but I feel bad and the one man working there was friendly, so I give them 2.
author: P A U L.

description: My friends and I usually come here for lunch on Fridays. After multiple visits to this place, I can safely say that I will no longer be coming back. We got to Henry's around 12:15pm. It was not very crowded and yet it took 1 hour to get our food. Our lunch break was only an hour long, so, after waiting an hour,  we decided to take ask for our food to go without even getting a chance to dine in. The worst part about was that people that arrived 20 minutes after us were served their food before us. Service was terrible.
author: David T.

description:
Spicy green beans and delicious garlic sauce makes me question how 'vegetarian' the food really is... but it's SO good I'm on a "Don't Ask, Don't Tell" kind of policy with them... 
At lunch it's packed with the fi-di crowds but it does a mean take-out and if you ask for it spicy, beware, they really know how to turn it up a notch!
author: Anjali K.

description: A single strong dish does not a 5-star restaurant make. I think it's solid for lunch when you're looking for something in the Financial District, but it's nothing to write home about. The last time I ordered Kung Pao chicken it was so so.
author: Jim B.

description: After one visit, I was torn between 3 and 4 stars.  But I willing to go back and re-evaluate.  We got two dishes, and both were supposed to be spicy, only one of them was.  The garlic chicken was forgettable.   The spicy shrimp was yummmmm!  I agree, the prices do seem on the high side.  For lunch, I prefer to have smaller rice plates for a smaller price.  We kept eating after we were full, just because there wasn't enough food to make it worth bringing it back to the office.  The service was pretty fast.  The walls are an abysmal shade of pepto pink.
author: Nikki c.

description: This is my first review on yelp due to the worst Kung Pao Beef I've ever tasted. The dish was extremely salty. I just couldn't finish it. I'll give this place two stars only because I haven't tried other dishes. A friend added that his Kung Pao chicken was rather salty and we would have been better off going to a cheaper Chinese restaurant near by.
author: L R.

description: Perhaps I was just really hungry, but everything our table ordered was fantastic.  The place was packed, and I'll be back.
author: Nick S.

description: Good place, good food, fast service...The meat pie is very good, as well as the kung pow shrimp. Try the Marty special and the orange chicken too....ask them to make it as spicy or not as you like....Good place for a small lunch party...
author: Michael M.

description: I do takeout, and Henry's while decent is not anything special.  The dish many say is the best, chicken with string beans comes in a black bean sauce and while flavorful and with just the right amount of spice, it also is overly salty.  Could be personal taste, but to me, I need to drink a gallon of water to adjust for the saltiness (not the spicyness).  They are quick and cheap though, so one plus in an area where lunch is very expensive!
author: Ab B.

description: Best damn Chinese food in San Francisco.  Quality between Henry's varies.  This is the best one.
author: Thomas H.

description: We ordered Diana's meat pie which is like a Chinese tostata.  My basic rule of thumb is if you stuff anything between two pieces of fried anything, it's gotta be good and it was tasty (tho it would have been better with melted cheese).  The kung pao chicken lacked the kung and the pao - it was all onions and peppers.  For those two items and 1 coke the bill came to $25 after tax and tip - kinda pricey for an average lunchtime experience.
author: mia s.

description: Great Chinese lunch place. Sit at the counter if you want watch the old Chinese laides cook over the hot woks.  Be careful if you do this but watch out becuase you'll stink like Hunan for the rest of the day. I think the best dishers are the meat pie, spicy rock cod filet, curry chicken.  Try something new everytime you go. It's always hot, fast spicy and delicious. For a more formal engagement try the Flagship restaurant on Sansome.
author: Brian B.

description: Keep It Simple Stupid.  They do a good job for what they are, cheap spicy chinese food.  Don't expect healthy or a grand decor.  Get there before 12:30PM or expect a wait.  The counter is a great place for yourself and sometimes a friend.  Take out is super easy.  I suggest the lunch specials, ask what they are for the day.
author: Chris S.

description: Skip this location and go to the SOMA one... Too crowded, slow service and just seems worse than the one down south. The selection even seems different!
author: Catherine R.

description: Had dinner here in Oct 1999 prior to a screening of Princess Mononoke (Mononoke-hime) at the Embarcadero. Needless to say, I haven't been back. There are several other locations, and the original started almost 30 years ago. Apparently popular with the lunch crowd for its gigantic portions and cheap prices, the unpretentious and possibly sad no-frills interior aren't really made up for by the food. This is one of those places where they charge you for extra rice and so you have to make do with the measly little bowl they give. Rice is cheap, it should be free. Any decent Asian restaurant will give you more rice without charging for it. Service, needless to say, is not so great either. For these prices, Great China in Berkeley is better.
author: Hao L.

description: For people that work in the Financial District like myself love this place!  Every person I've met that works downtown knows this place and always says to try this dish or that dish.  Well people in my office order from them at least twice a week, and sometimes 3 times on a good week.  Definitely try the dumplings, chicken with string beans (or any meat with string beans), kung pao chicken, beef and broccoli, hot and sour beef, marty's special, henry's special, and the Diana meat pie.  It's definitely not the healthiest meal you can eat, but its definitely one of the tastiest
author: Maria B.

description: Best Chinese food in the Financial District. They hand make their Dumplings which tastes fantastic. Their Beef with broccoli, Beef stew and many other dishes are absolutely delicious. Me and Co-Worker use to walk from the ballpark at least once a week to eat there. Now I work much closer and introduced new co-workers to this place. Fantastic, not 1 dish I don't like. Not your typical American Chinese restaurant,  my friend from China loved this place and use to order stuff that wasn't even on the menu. A+++++
author: Gregory F.

description:
I went here looking for some legit Chinese food in China TOWN!!!  This was the first place we saw, as we were roaming through China town.  I decided to roll the dice.
The people in this place are friendly as hell!  You can tell there were a lot of regulars as everybody seemed to be on a first name basis with each other.  
Anyway, we ordered some noods and spicy chicken and both items were bomb.  Not to mention, that the chefs seemed pretty much like the coolest guys ever.  They kind of reminded me of that guy who won top chef - hong
Enough said - check it out    and it was cheap
author: Buddy Garrity L.

description:
Yum, yum, quadruple yum!  I was a happy camper during lunch.  Food was hot, spiced perfectly as ordered, and OH SO TASTY!  I can't wait to go back.  And super reasonably priced!  

Head upstairs for the nicest servers.
author: Michele O.

description: We order this for my work every so often and I have to decline. I have tried you oh HH. But every single time, I end up in the bathroom bent over with pain. Entirely too greasy, even for greasy chinese. Not worth the pain in my book.
author: Brownie G.

description:
It's a block from my office, so for a while I was attracted by the convenience for lunch-time takeout, and co-workers had given it rave reviews (as if it were the New Nirvana).  The food was good, but not great.  They refused to accommodate any special requests -- or simply ignored them, which is even worse in my opinion.  I asked repeatedly for "no rice" or "light rice" only to get back to the office and discover that the take-out box was, as usual, filled with 50-60% rice.

I suspect that they honor special requests from people who are actually eating at the restaurant, but why shouldn't take-out customers get the same treatment?

I haven't been to Henry's for several months, and I don't plan to return.
author: Dennis H.

description: I don't get all the reviews talking about how spicy this place is. I think it's good, flavorful food, but my one serious gripe about it is that it's nowhere near spicy enough to qualify as real Hunan food - or even to meet my white-girl spice requirements. In fairness, I haven't yet gone out of my way to ask for anything extra-spicy, and I bet they would do that if you asked. But what is up with all the whining about the spiciness? Bring it, Henry's!
author: Erica W.

description: This is a great lunch spot.  I love sitting at the counter and watching the women crank out the food at an alarming rate.  The dumplings are super good.  They have great lunch specials that I believe are $6.50 each and there are 3 to chose from each day.  I normally wouldn't order chow mein but the chick chow mein is spicy, not greasy and good.  All the food is very fresh.  I recommend coming after the lunch rush.
author: Gina T.

description:
what can warm you up on a cold, foggy summer day in sf?  henry's of course!  if you love spicy, then you'll love henry's.  kung pao chicken (w/ extra peanuts), garlic green beans, and combo chow mein is our department's usual lunch fare, maybe an onion cake every now and then (when we're feeling like something not spicy!).  even the chow mein is spicy, and so you'll need plenty of plain rice, water and deep breaths to simmer down - but it burns so good!  i remember one time, a co-worker asked for the kung pao "spicy" and the waitress raised her eyebrow at him, as if to say "you dare?" and the kitchen rose to the challenge - i've never had a spicier kung pao kick!  i think i'm starting to sweat just thinking about it.

yes, it's a hole in the wall, and perhaps it wouldn't hurt to rinse your chopsticks in a little tea, but i swear the food tastes better at this location than at the "nicer" spot on natoma.

always crowded at lunch, try to arrive before noon or call in your order for pick-up.
author: Jen P.

description: My friend Debita took me here for my first time and I was like this place is gonna suck, run down old buliding. she has been coming here for years and all the staff know her by name, so I let her order for us which was a smart move.We sat upstairs which isnt much better visualy. But when the food came, GOOD GAWD was it good. I had the Henrys special which is a seafood chow mein and I keep going back at least once a week.
author: Tony P.

description: It's some pretty greasy stuff.  But, it works when you go with a big crowd of your co-workers -- something for everyone.  Easy seating, fast service.
author: K W.

description: Five stars from me is a lot, but I just have to say: their dumplings are worth the price of admission to any other restaurant.  Fat, juicy and spicey: one order of 6 is enough to call it a lunch. People like me often go for 2 orders for 12 dumplings and then scarf it all down.  Yes, they are that good. I have tried other dishes there, and each of the others were quite good. But at Henry's, they know me now as the Dumpling Man.
author: Chris C.

description: I Love Henty's, the smoked ham chow mein is my favorite
author: Natasha C.

description: There was a reason this place got written up in Gourmet.  Great Chinese food....like everyone says.  it can get packed with the financial district crowd,  but i walked in, placed a to-go order, and was out in 10-15 minutes, so thats not bad at all.....had the matty's special...a little salty, but tasty. i'm looking forward to trying their other dishes....
author: Pete D.

description: This is a great place if you want a Chinese restaurant experience.  Which means the service is so bad, all you can do is laugh.  The food hits the spot when you are looking for the unhealthy greasy Chinese food.  My coworkers and I always get the Noodle #1 or 2.  When it comes out it looks like dog food, but its delicious and cheap dog food.
author: Brent G.

description: great spicy food! I tried garlic chicken and kung pao beef (super super hot) and they were both very good!
author: Rayid G.

description: Black Bean Chicken is my favorite.  The plus and minus is that it is across the street from my office so I sometimes crave it and then wish I did not eat it since it is so filling.  Service is prompt and the place is reasonably clean.
author: Dan G.

description: I've been a big fan of this Hunan restaurant since I first arrived in San Francisco in 1979.  It was the first Chinese restaurant to serve Hunan style food and, in my mind, is still the best.  I've tried nearly every dish on their menu and never been disappointed. I've turned quite a few friends onto it and every one of them has loved it.  If you like hot and spicy Chinese food, this is the place for you!
author: Joe B.

description: This is one of four places in SF that i recommend for chinese.  Its cheap, it's fast and it's good.  My favorite dish is hot and sour beef over rice, it's basically what i go there for.  I'd wish they  invest some money in updating the interior of this particular location.  they have a lot of 8x11 signs on the walls with the specials.... using scotch tape....i digress.....
author: erica u.

description: Yummy! If you like spicy, you'll love Henry. Try Marty's Special (assuming you're not a vegetarian)
author: Damian T.

description: This place won't win any awards for ambiance, but the food is rock solid.  i have eaten at this restaurant a hundred times and never been disappointed.  very reasonably priced for a restaurant downtown, they make some of the best chicken curry i have ever eaten.  i know they have other locations, but i have only eaten at the one on sansome and was equally impressed (maybe moreso because they have a full bar).  highly recommended!
author: Tony S.

description:
I'm glad they give you a huge bowl of rice because after any dish your mouth will be on fire.  The food was nice and tasty though, especially the chicken with green beans.  

Be prepared for a little wait if you go at noon.  Do you go up stairs or downstairs, no one really knows?  Wrap up your leftovers for dinner and maybe even breakfast since the portions along with the spice were too much for one sitting.
author: Sean B.

description: This place is okay.  No msg but they sure pile on the sodium. I always leave this place thirsty........probably why you don't see many Asians dining here...........
author: JJ D.

description: I don't understand why people like this place so much.  Even for an honest, quick lunch place, there are much better places in the area.  We ordered the Henry's Pork, which is basically a spicy pork and cabbage dish.  The pork tasted old and musty and it was greasy. Flavor was basic, it was missing the bean paste which is kind of the signature flavor of the dish, plus WAY too many onions. My friend had beef with green onion (scallions). Horrible quality beef (marinated in tenderizer) and the whole thing was swimming in oil. Not alot of flavor because they used adult scallions rather than tender green onion shoots (what you are supposed to use). The fried rice at the next table looked ok, and some other lady's rice noodles looked decent as well, but nothing amazing.  I must have not ordered well, but at the same time what we got was pretty standard.  I much prefer the little Thai place right next door for the same price. The one bright spot, the service was friendly and good.
author: Priscilla C.

description: Flawless. The best Chinese food in SF, and that is really saying something. Get the smoked ham with string beans, it's mind-numbingly awesome.  All locations are equally great.
author: Mister D.

description: Place was a little scary but the food was pretty good.  Not a place I would take people before I had been there myself.  I would go back and just be ready for a nap after lunch or dinner.  Service was typical chinese food service.
author: Kareem B.

description: I've only had the Kung Pao chicken, but I eat it every week. If you like the heat, it's a great dish. I hear Marty's Special is also tremendous
author: Rich C.

description: if you're going to eat/order from here- don't play games, order the MEAT PIE.  i don't know what kinda meat it is, but it is GOOOOOD!  nice and spicy, super greasy, and absolutely tasty.  other things you can't pass up- garlic chicken, and their chicken in black bean sauce.  OH and thier dumplings- i get them everytime.  they're like steamed potstickers that sit in a SPICY soy type sauce.  delish!
author: Shanti G.

description: If it's Wednesday, go for the chicken with string bean special, comes with rice. I crave this. Good white meat chicken, spicy, spicy, spicy and loads of green beans, so it's healthy, right? The lunch specials come served over rice. Ambiance lacks so get it to-go and be ready for the spice. If you like to sweat while you eat, this is the place for you.
author: Cbr A.

description: I as not a fan, but I am a fan now! I still don't like eating there. Service is slow because it is so crowded.   Sometimes, when I call the phone just rings and rings.. But, I still get my lunch there because the noodles and pork with spicy special sauce is that addicting!!!! I also like the dumplings. I DO NOT like the hot and sour chicken.
author: vernice l.

description:
only open during weekdays.

my all around favorite chinese restaurant. The owner boxes up food for the homeless every day at 2pm! It's often nearly impossible to find parking but the owner let me order from outside and sit on the hood of my car and then she brought it out to me!

Everything is good, but I'd probably stick to one of the specials. Ignore the "special of the day" because they'll make anything you order. The one that stood out to me was Kung Pao Pork. Everything is very spicy but oppressively so.

i've had bad experiences at the Noe Valley location (bland, slow service) so go to the original on Sacramento St.
author: blimp w.

description: for 8 years straight i ate here twice a week, (you do the math). Linda is the sweetest host in chinatown.  over time i narrowed down what i ate to kung pao chix (best anywhere).  the chix chow mein,  sweet sour beef, string been with beef or chix. and pot stickers.  meat pie was to greasy for me.  ahh but that was years ago before moving to Marin.  A couple of  months ago i stopped into Bryant street location for take out.  now i drive in once a week to haul back over the bridge.  worth the toll..
author: George M.

description: Strolling around wanting some Chinese food for lunch one day we saw this hole in the wall and said lets go for it.  This would have gotten a 5 star vote had it not been for the loooong ass time to get the food.  I think they forgot our order because after about 15 min the waiter made a strange glance at our table and then ran back to the kitchen... the food came about 15 min after that.  Anyways, the food was killer.  the noodles were prob the best i've had in this city, and the hot and sour chicken was no joke either.  large portions, great taste, good crowd all adds up to a pretty chill spot.
author: Shane L.

description: 5 stars = "as good as it gets".  To me, for Chinese, that's Henry's on Sac Street.  Rolled in there yesterday at 11:45 and had the hot n sour beef rice plate.  $6.75 for a little bit of piping hot, fresh from the wok heaven.  I used to frequent the original location on Sansome in the early 90's and have always been a fan.  But I'd never been to this Sac Street satellite location.  After a few years away, I was loving every bite yesterday.  This is Chinese food that assualts all your senses, smells good, looks good, tastes good, feels good and has a nice spicy bite to it.  If you like spicy hot Chinese, this is the place to go.  And I didn't even have any smoked ham dishes.........my mouth is literally watering just thinking about it.  They got me in and out fast and it was the tastiest lunch I've had in months.  Henry's rules.  Interesting note, I think there were only two or three women in the full restaurant.  Is Henry's dude food?
author: Russ T.
